Buttigieg continued, â€œThey go for something that is so outrageous that you actually canâ€™t ignore it. The media canâ€™t ignore whatâ€™s going on, because very real pain has been inflicted on and fear, by the way, on people in this community and other communities around the country.â€ Sen. Joe Manchin, the conservative Democrat-turned-independent who had toyed with a presidential run and has long been a thorn in the side of the left, has been mum about the candidate heâ€™s backing in November. But that could soon change, as Manchin signaled he may get off the sidelines and plans to speak to Vice President Kamala Harris soon. Sen. Mitt Romney, the Republican Partyâ€™s 2012 presidential nominee who voted twice to convict former President Donald Trump in his impeachment trials, reiterated his disdain for Trump â€“ and objected to the former presidentâ€™s refusal to say at last weekâ€™s debate that he wanted Ukraine to win its war against Russia. Asked twice if he could endorse Harris, Romney pointedly refused to say. The comments by Manchin and Romney â€“ two retiring senators who have been on the outs with their respective partyâ€™s base â€“ underscore how Trump has turned off some more moderate voters but also how Harris herself has yet to close the deal with right-leaning voters turned off by the former president. A third Trump detractor, GOP Sen. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, doesnâ€™t plan to vote for Harris, even as she said of the former presidentâ€™s debate performance, â€œI donâ€™t think it was Donald Trumpâ€™s best evening.â€ Read more here. Wittenberg University in Springfield, Ohio, is taking â€œextreme precautionsâ€ in response to an email that threatened an on-campus shooting targeting Haitians on Sunday, according to university officials. The threat comes as several prominent Republicans, including former President Donald Trump and his running mate, Sen. JD Vance, have promoted false claims that Haitian migrants in Ohio are killing and eating family pets. Local officials at the city and state level have repeatedly tried to end the rumor. Springfield officials have told press and city commission meetings that there are no credible reports of animal abuse by immigrants in the area. The threat to Wittenberg University â€œtargeted Haitian members of our community,â€ a statement released Saturday said. â€œWittenberg Police are cooperating with the Springfield Police Division and the FBI to investigate this threat.â€   All activities have been canceled on Sunday, and the Springfield Police Division will increase patrols on campus, the universityâ€™s statement said, adding that those who are on or near campus should â€œprepare for additional instructions or a lockdown if we learn more from the ongoing investigation.â€ Wittenberg University had 1,288 undergraduate students enrolled in the fall 2023 term, according to its website. CNN has reached out to the Wittenberg Police Department for additional information.  Donald Trump wanted to spend this week attacking one of Democratic rival Kamala Harrisâ€™ biggest political vulnerabilities. Instead, he spent most of the week falsely claiming that migrants are eating pets in a small town in Ohio and defending his embrace of a far-right agitator whose presence is causing concern among his allies. Trumpâ€™s repeated parroting of unfounded social media rumors about Haitian migrants in Ohio eating pets stole headlines during a trip West, including stops in Arizona and Nevada, late this week. The promotion of the claims overshadowed a series of speeches aimed at the economy and blaming Harris for border security failures. Trump, in a news conference in California on Friday, promised â€œlarge deportationsâ€ from Springfield, Ohio â€” the town that has become a political flashpoint as Republicans, including Trump and his running mate, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, spread false claims about Haitian immigrants eating pets. The city of Springfield notes on its website that approximately 12,000 to 15,000 immigrants live in Clark County, and that Haitian immigrants are there legally as part of a parole program that allows citizens and lawful residents to apply to have their family members from Haiti come to the United States. Read more here. New polling post-debate from ABC News and Ipsos finds Vice President Kamala Harris leading former President Donald Trump among likely voters, with the margin in the race unchanged from ABC News polling conducted in late August.  Overall, 52% of likely voters back Harris, 46% Trump in the poll, the same margin the pollsters found among likely voters in an August 23 through 27 poll. Among adults, the survey suggests little change in the dynamic between the candidates on the campaignâ€™s central issues. Trump continues to be more widely trusted to handle the economy (46% Trump to 39% Harris) and immigration (47% Trump to 37% Harris), while Harris is broadly more trusted on abortion (48% Harris to 34% Trump) and protecting American democracy (45% Harris to 38% Trump). The ABC News poll was conducted online Sept. 11-13 among a random national sample of 3,276 adults and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 2 points. For results among the 2,196 likely voters, the error margin is plus or minus 2 points. Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ campaign and Nebraska Democratic officials are keeping a close eye on any last-minute efforts to change the election law that awards the stateâ€™s electoral votes by congressional district, rather than statewide winner. Nebraskaâ€™s unique law presents an opportunity for Democrats to secure one of the stateâ€™s votes by winning the district surrounding Omaha â€” a critical blue dot in a sea of red. The stateâ€™s Republican Gov. Jim Pillen made it clear Friday that he is willing to call a special legislative session on changing the state to a â€œwinner takes allâ€ model before the November election â€” but said in a statement that he doesnâ€™t yet have â€œconcrete and public indicationâ€ that enough lawmakers would back the move. Nebraska Democratic chairwoman Jane Kleeb said Saturday that Pillenâ€™s statement signals Republicans â€œdo not have the votes to change the fair electoral system we have in Nebraska.â€ When the matter of changing the law came up for a vote in the state legislature earlier this year, it was 17 votes shy of passing. Kleeb said Saturday that those 17 votes remain â€œvery solid.â€ Bottom line: If Vice President Kamala Harris can win the â€œblue wallâ€ states of Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania, plus the blue dot vote in Nebraska, she can likely reach 270 electoral votes without winning a single other contested battleground state. That means a potential change to the law â€” which would be a shocking development so close to the election â€” could have serious implications for each presidential campaign. Democratic vice presidential nominee Tim Walz made a direct pitch to Muslim and Arab American voters in Michigan, addressing those concerned about the Biden administrationâ€™s handling of the war in Gaza. The Minnesota governor used an interview Friday to reiterate Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ support for a ceasefire-hostage deal between Israel and Hamas, and argued Trumpâ€™s record of targeting Muslim Americans is â€œnot in your best interest.â€ Harris is more cognizant of the suffering of Palestinians than Trump, Walz said in the interview with WXMI in Grand Rapids, Michigan, addressing those from the â€œAbandon Harrisâ€ movement. Illustrating the constant balancing act for the Democratic ticket on the Middle East, Walz also emphasized the importance of Israelâ€™s self-defense. â€œThatâ€™s why sheâ€™s the person to move us toward a two-state solution, where Israel can be protected, we get our hostages back, and Gaza can be self-determined,â€ he added. Walz contrasted Harrisâ€™ view with Trumpâ€™s previous support of a travel ban that targeted people from Muslim-majority countries, and his calls to send some Muslim members of Congress to their countries of origin. â€œDonald Trump is offering you nothing,â€ Walz said, to voters skeptical of Harris over the issue. â€œThat is not in your best interest.â€

Title: Texts, tough love, campaign advice and strategy dinners â€“ the women Kamala Harris has mentored | CNN Politics
Content: Backstage, Kamala Harris pulled aside Jahana Hayes. Sheâ€™d give the congresswoman her local press boost and photo op, but first, the vice president needed to talk about why she was popping into Connecticut of all places during the final month of her 2022 midterm campaigning: Hayes wasnâ€™t raising enough money. Pick it up, Harris told her. National Democrats wouldnâ€™t stick with Hayes if she didnâ€™t help herself. Long before she became the Democratic presidential nominee, Harris had started quietly nurturing a network of next-generation politicians â€“ almost all women of color, many with backgrounds in the law, many who didnâ€™t know who else was in the group. Often, that has been through check-in calls offering encouragement and advice, many of these women told CNN, though sometimes Harris will interrogate them on the specifics of campaign strategy or push them on how theyâ€™re dealing with labor or other constituencies. She was on a running text thread with Massachusetts Rep. Ayanna Pressley. She counseled longtime friend and former aide Laphonza Butler through the frenetic weekend last fall that ended with Butlerâ€™s appointment to the Senate. She hosted a collection of Black congresswomen for a dinner at the Naval Observatory, the vice presidentâ€™s residence. Tears can flow. Major life-changing decisions get made. Harris always asks about their kids. And along the way, these relationships have become core for Harris herself â€“ as a mission for a politician who takes seriously her motherâ€™s admonition to be the first but not the last. Theyâ€™re also a comfort for a vice president who remembers well her own loneliness as she worked her way up and serve as a base of support for a politician who until July had seen much of the Democratic establishment turn on her. â€œShe checks in on people that nobody else pays attention to,â€ said Rep. Jasmine Crockett, a first-term congresswoman from Texas who teared up last month recalling the first time the two met â€“ in a photo line during a reception on Crockettâ€™s first visit to the Naval Observatory. Harris looked at her and said, â€œWhatâ€™s wrong?â€ Crockett said that it wasnâ€™t until that moment that she realized how overwhelmed she felt wondering if sheâ€™d made a mistake running for Congress, on top of the stress of battling with Republicans on the House Oversight Committee in defense of President Joe Biden. Harris, Crockett said, â€œsaw right through me,â€ as she felt only another Black woman who had experienced the same pressures and bruises of politics could. With Harris within reach of the Oval Office, these women feel the pride of now supporting her, but also of what her win would mean to them, the issues they have connected on and their own careers. Many who had never imagined careers in politics boggle at the idea of a president who might look like them and know them by name. Angela Alsobrooks, the Democratic nominee for Senate in Maryland, has started collecting magazines with Harris on the cover, buttons, a T-shirt and other memorabilia. Lateefah Simon, who first met Harris over 20 years ago when the young San Francisco assistant district attorney reached out to Simon as the leader of a group for young girls in trouble, is now all but certain to win an open House seat anchored in Oakland. She broke down sobbing during Maya Harrisâ€™ convention speech when thinking of her own memories of the vice presidentâ€™s mother. Simon likes to joke that whenever an unknown caller comes up, itâ€™s either her student loan company or Harris. When she got one of those calls in March, it was Harris with a congratulations and what Simon says was â€œthe most beautiful pep talk that Iâ€™ve ever had from anybody,â€ hours before the primary polls closed. If Harris will soon be making those calls from the White House, to Simon that would be the ultimate proof of the biggest lesson she has learned from Harris over the years: â€œThat this thing is doable, that we donâ€™t need to have legacy or families that are multimillionaires,â€ she said. â€œThere is a road to leadership.â€ Now about a month shy of 60, Harris is not that much older than most of these women, but she is older enough and has been credited enough times for being a â€œfirstâ€ in the offices she has won. She came into their lives in different ways, at different points. Alsobrooks read an article about Harrisâ€™ restorative justice work as San Francisco district attorney in Essence magazine when she was running to be a county prosecutor in Maryland and started talking about it on the trail. Then, a few days after she won, her phone rang. â€œâ€™Hi, itâ€™s Kamala Harris,â€™â€ Alsobrooks remembers hearing. She was shocked. â€œCan you imagine like youâ€™re talking about someone you read about in a magazine? I didnâ€™t even know she knew I existed,â€ Alsobrooks told CNN after a recent campaign stop. â€œNot only did she call, but she said, â€˜Tell me, how I can help you?â€™â€ Alsobrooks ended up flying to San Francisco, where Harris set her up with meetings, including with people at Goodwill Industries, who oversaw the workforce development program that had partnered with Harrisâ€™ office, and with a judge who helped guide younger offenders toward the restorative justice program. They hit it off, and years later, Harris invited Alsobrooks back across the country to ride her campaign bus for the final stretch of her 2016 Senate campaign. For Massachusetts Attorney General Andrea Campbell, the first time she saw Harris was when the then-district attorney spoke at her 2009 UCLA law school commencement. She was intrigued, went to fundraisers for Harris in Boston and flew to California for her Senate election victory party. â€œJoyâ€ was the theme of the Democratic convention in August, but Alsobrooks and Campbell say that Harris has been stressing the word to them for years. To Campbell, it wasnâ€™t just pushing an ephemeral feeling, but encouraging her not to shy away from speaking about the time her father and brothers spent in prison. Harris â€œalways encouraged me, offered love and guidance on how not to be distracted by those who would want to use it against me,â€ Campbell said. Instead, she used that story to pull people â€œinto the political fold where they may feel as though politics and government isnâ€™t for them.â€ Harrisâ€™s advice hits a few consistent beats: â€œNone of it is personal,â€ â€œDonâ€™t internalize it,â€ â€œCome early and stay late,â€ â€œStay focused on your whyâ€ and, perhaps most consistently, â€œIf it was easy, everyone would do this.â€ â€œShe wants us to understand the reality of what it means to be a Black woman running for higher office, that there are significant challenges: Itâ€™s much harder to fundraise. It can be more challenging to break through, including in the media, to cover your race or to cover your story with the thoughtfulness maybe it deserves,â€ Campbell said. But sometimes the advice is specific. Malia Cohen, now the California state controller, first met Harris as a volunteer for Gavin Newsomâ€™s mayoral campaign in San Francisco, but then she got interested in the young Black woman who was running for district attorney. Cohen switched over to Harrisâ€™ campaign for a few shifts. When Cohen launched her own campaign years later for the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, a man she met with to ask for an endorsement invited her to a Bruce Springsteen concert and offered to buy her drinks. Cohen remembered telling Harris on a call what happened. â€œShe said, â€˜When youâ€™re talking to these guys, stick to your guns, talk business, and make it very, very clear that this is not a date,â€™â€ Cohen recalled. â€œAnd I asked her if she ever experienced that and she said, â€˜No. All of these men know that when Iâ€™m in the room, that Iâ€™m about business.â€™ And that was the end of that.â€ Daniele Monroe-Moreno, the Nevada Democratic Party chair and the speaker pro tempore of the state Assembly, was at a luncheon in Las Vegas when she met Harris, not long after the Senate win. They started talking about the maternal health legislation Monroe-Moreno was working on. â€œKamala said, â€˜Iâ€™ve been working on that myself. Can I help you?â€™ And I thought, â€˜Sure, OK, you can help meâ€™. But sheâ€™s a senator, right? Sheâ€™s busy,â€ Monroe-Moreno remembered. â€œBut just a few weeks later, I get a call, and itâ€™s one of her staff, who said, â€˜Hey, my boss is Kamala Harris, and she said youâ€™re working on a policy, and weâ€™ve done a lot of research.â€™â€ Two weeks of collaborating and wrangling with colleagues later, the bill passed. Monroe-Moreno said she doubts the law would have ended up on the books without that help. Peggy Flanagan, the lieutenant governor of Minnesota, hasnâ€™t had as many encounters with Harris, but the ones sheâ€™s had stick with her. In the spring, backstage at an EMILYâ€™s List gala, Flanagan â€” who is of Native American heritage â€” was going on about how great it was to see the video the vice presidentâ€™s office had just put out with the old cast of â€œA Different Worldâ€ about the administrationâ€™s work on student debt. Before Harris went out onstage, Flanagan said, â€œShe grabbed me by my shoulders and said, â€˜I want you to know that I have your back.â€™â€ The loyalty runs both ways. Campbell, seven months pregnant at the time, flew to Iowa to campaign for Harris during her unsuccessful bid for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination. And amid the early Democratic implosion around Bidenâ€™s candidacy in July, Hayes spoke out in a private meeting of her House colleagues, worried that if the vice president was suddenly asked to take over a doomed campaign, sheâ€™d get an undue share of the blame. The afternoon that Biden dropped out and Harris started ticking through dozens of calls, it wasnâ€™t just senior leaders and potential rivals who heard from her. â€œI donâ€™t know how I made the cut,â€ Crockett said. â€œIt was a call of gratitude, and just, â€˜I want to say thank you.â€™â€ Campbell recalled goosebumps and tears that day. Alsobrooks said the pride she feels in seeing Harrisâ€™ campaign take off in the weeks since is like that â€œfor a sister.â€ As much as theyâ€™re rooting for and working toward Harrisâ€™ win, though, these women still havenâ€™t quite wrapped their heads around the idea that if she does, beyond all the greater meaning politically and culturally, the next president of the United States would be the woman who for so many years has just been Kamala on the other end of the phone. For women who never saw themselves in elected office, thatâ€™s an overwhelming thought anyway. But to imagine that the president would be a woman who helped and inspired them get to where they are, itâ€™s much more. â€œIt is not just like, Iâ€™d be proud sheâ€™s president. I just know what she endured,â€ Alsobrooks said. â€œThis is a person who, over 30 years, worked hard. So the pride I feel is not that I drank the Kool-Aid. Sheâ€™d be president, and I would be proud of that. But I am so proud of her.â€

Title: Fact check: Harris campaign social media account has repeatedly deceived with misleading edits and captions | CNN Politics
Content: A social media account run by Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ campaign has been repeatedly deceptive. The @KamalaHQ account, which has more than 1.3 million followers on the X social media platform formerly known as Twitter, has made a habit of misleadingly clipping and inaccurately captioning video clips to attack former President Donald Trump. The Harris campaign deploys @KamalaHQ as a kind of irreverent attack dog, using jocular posts to draw attention to controversial, incorrect, or dubious comments by Trump and his allies. But the account, which the Harris campaign calls its â€œofficial rapid response page,â€ has itself made inaccurate comments on multiple occasions. Below are eight examples of false or misleading video posts from the account since mid-August, including three from the latter part of this week. All of them have previously been highlighted by an anonymous rebuttal account called @KamalaHQLies, which itself has more than 268,000 followers. Misleadingly describing a Trump comment about his supporters An August 17 post from @KamalaHQ strongly suggested Trump had gotten confused about what state he was in during an event in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. The post said, â€œTrump: Would that be okay, North Carolina? (He is in Pennsylvania).â€ It included a six-second video clip in which Trump said, while pointing to his left, â€œWould that be okay, North Carolina? I donâ€™t think so, right.â€ The Harris campaign was explicit about its intentions in the version of the post it made on the Instagram @KamalaHQ account, saying, â€œDonald Trump is lost and confused.â€ But Trump was not lost or confused. The full video of the rally shows that earlier in the speech, Trump had pointed to the same spot on his left to acknowledge and then speak to a group of ardent supporters from North Carolina, eventually saying, â€œThank you very much. North Carolina!â€ Later, in the moment shown by @KamalaHQ, he pointed to these supporters again and referred to them as â€œNorth Carolina.â€ He had not forgotten he was speaking in Pennsylvania. The Harris campaign declined to comment on this @KamalaHQ post. Deceptively clipping and misleadingly describing a Trump comment about immigration On Thursday, the @KamalaHQ account made a new attempt to suggest that Trump was confused about his location. Its post said, â€œTrump: â€˜Pennsylvania, remember this when you have to go to voteâ€™ (He is in Arizona).â€ It included an eight-second clip of Trump saying in a Tucson speech, â€œSo Pennsylvania, remember this when you have to go to vote, okay, just remember this: 2,000% increase. This is a small â€”â€¦â€ The Instagram post of this remark, too, was more explicit than the X post; on Instagram, the Harris campaign added text over top the video that read, â€œTrump forgets which state he is in (again).â€ But Trump, again, had not forgotten which state he was in. The extended footage shows that the Harris campaign clipped out critical context: Trump was talking about immigration, a key topic in Arizona, and had just read a part of his prepared text about how a small Pennsylvania town has â€œexperienced a 2,000% increase in the population of Haitian migrants under Kamala Harris.â€ He then added, â€œSo Pennsylvania, remember this when you have to go to vote, okay, just remember this: 2,000% increase, this is a small town; of all a sudden they got thousands of people.â€ One could try to argue itâ€™s odd for Trump to make a direct appeal to Pennsylvanians while speaking in Arizona. But Trumpâ€™s remarks anywhere in the country are broadcast to voters everywhere in the country, and, regardless, @KamalaHQ eliminated the context that would allow people to develop an informed opinion on this remark. The Harris campaign declined to comment on this @KamalaHQ post. Deceptively clipping and misleadingly describing a Trump comment about his 2017 Charlottesville remark A Friday post from @KamalaHQ said, â€œTrump says â€˜nothing was done wrongâ€™ in Charlottesville in 2017 when neo-Nazis chanted â€˜Jews will not replace usâ€™ and killed an innocent woman.â€ The post included a 10-second clip of Trump telling reporters at a Friday event in California, â€œâ€¦like on Project 2025, I have no idea about â€” had nothing to do with me, he didnâ€™t correct her, he knew that. Charlottesville â€” nothing was done wrong.â€ But the full video of Trumpâ€™s California comments shows that the Harris campaign deceptively cut the clip right before Trump made clear he was not claiming that neo-Nazis in Charlottesville did nothing wrong or that the murder of innocent Charlottesville counterprotester Heather Heyer was not wrong. Rather, the full video shows, he was arguing that he did nothing wrong with his â€œvery fine people, on both sidesâ€ comment in 2017 about the events in Charlottesville, which he has repeatedly insisted was not about white nationalists. Specifically, Trump was complaining that a moderator of the presidential debate on Tuesday, David Muir of ABC News, did not challenge how Harris described Trumpâ€™s 2017 comments. We say Harrisâ€™ debate description of the 2017 comments was fair, but regardless, Trump was not defending murder on Friday. Here is Trumpâ€™s full Friday remark, in which he invoked various Fox News hosts: â€œI think he (Muir) corrected me 11 times. Of the 11 times, I donâ€™t think he had the right to correct me at all. Didnâ€™t correct her once. Like on Project 2025, I have no idea about â€” had nothing to do with me, he didnâ€™t correct her, he knew that. Charlottesville â€” nothing was done wrong. All you had to do is read my statement one more sentence and you wouldâ€™ve seen that. Sean Hannity, Laura Ingraham, Jesse (Watters), all of them, they â€” Greg Gutfeld â€” they all took that and they corrected it many times. But they keep coming with the same lies.â€ Defending the @KamalaHQ post, the Harris campaign said in an email: â€œHeâ€™s saying he did â€˜nothing wrongâ€™ in relation to him saying â€˜very fine peopleâ€™ who did what is described in the tweet.â€ There are two problems with this. The post itself did not acknowledge that Trumpâ€™s â€œnothing wrongâ€ comment was about his own previous remark. And while thereâ€™s a solid case that this 2017 â€œvery fine peopleâ€ comment was about some white nationalists, thereâ€™s no basis for claiming it was about Heyerâ€™s murderer in particular â€” much less that Trumpâ€™s â€œnothing wrongâ€ comment on Friday was about this murderer. Deceptively clipping and inaccurately quoting a JD Vance quote about veteransâ€™ health care On Thursday, the @KamalaHQ account posted a nine-second video clip of Sen. JD Vance, Trumpâ€™s running mate, speaking in an interview. The account wrote: â€œQ: Would you consider privatizing veterans health care? Vance: I think Iâ€™d consider it.â€ But Vance did not actually say â€œI think Iâ€™d consider it.â€ A close listen to the clip reveals Vance actually said â€œI think Iâ€™d consider â€” andâ€¦â€ And because @KamalaHQ clipped out the critical comments he made after the â€œand,â€ the Harris campaign didnâ€™t allow people to immediately learn just what Vance said he would consider. The extended Vance quote shows he said he would consider giving veterans greater flexibility to use private health care but that he does not want to eliminate federal health care provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). A public-private combination for veteransâ€™ care was the general approach taken by President Barack Obama and then by Trump; itâ€™s certainly not without critics, but itâ€™s much less contentious than the idea of a total privatization. Hereâ€™s the full Vance quote: â€œI think Iâ€™d consider â€” and Donald Trump was really good at this, doesnâ€™t get enough credit for this particular innovation â€” giving veterans more choice. Right? So letâ€™s say youâ€™re in a rural hospital. Your closest VA is 120 miles away. Why force a veteran to drive two-and-a-half hours to that VA facility when he can get cheaper and good care right in his backyard? Right? So I do think that we ought to open up choice and optionality for veterans. You know, I think that there is areas where the VA actually works very well, so I wouldnâ€™t say get rid of the whole thing. I would say give people more choice, I think youâ€™ll save money in the process, youâ€™ll also give veterans a lot more optionality.â€ The Harris campaign defended the @KamalaHQ post. It argued in its email, â€œVance is suggesting he would consider privatizing VA functions. This is not misleading. Our caption does not say â€˜the whole VA health system.â€™â€ But the Harris campaign did not address the captionâ€™s â€œconsider itâ€ misquote or explain why it cut the clip before people could hear Vance explain what he would â€œconsider.â€ And if the Harris campaign wanted to claim Vance was talking about possibly privatizing certain VA â€œfunctions,â€ as it said in the email, it could have said that in the post rather than at very least leaving open the impression he was talking about privatizing the whole VA. Vance spokesperson William Martin said the Harris campaign is â€œlyingâ€ about what Vance said. Martin said Vance â€œpersonally relied on the VA for years after leaving the Marine Corps,â€ that Vance does not even want to privatize VA â€œfunctions,â€ and that giving veterans more options to voluntarily choose private care cannot be fairly described as privatizing even parts of the VA. Martin said: â€œIn the full exchange, Senator Vance clearly says he would not privatize the Department of Veterans Affairs.â€ Deceptively clipping and falsely describing a Trump quote about penalties for damaging monuments The @KamalaHQ account frequently invokes Project 2025, the Heritage Foundation think tankâ€™s right-wing policy proposals for the next Republican administration. Project 2025 is not Trumpâ€™s initiative, and he has said he disagrees with some of its proposals, but he has extensive ties to the initiative; you can read more here. An August 30 post from @KamalaHQ said, â€œTrump says he plans to bring back laws from 100+ years ago, echoing Project 2025: â€˜We donâ€™t pass laws like that. They are tough.â€™â€ The post included a seven-second clip of Trump speaking at a rally in Pennsylvania. But the full video of the rally shows Trump was not even talking about Project 2025 or his future plans. Rather, Trump was telling his usual tale about how he supposedly â€œsignedâ€ a century-old law to give automatic 10-year prison sentences to people who were damaging monuments. Trumpâ€™s story is false â€” he didnâ€™t actually sign any law on monument-damage penalties or impose automatic 10-year sentences â€” but itâ€™s also false that he was â€œechoing Project 2025â€ or announcing some plan for a next Trump administration. The Harris campaign defended this @KamalaHQ post by arguing that â€œTrumpâ€™s entire platform is about embracing â€˜toughâ€™ policy of the pastâ€ on various subjects. Thatâ€™s another thin defense. The post made a specific claim about what Trump was supposedly saying in a specific video included in the post, and Trump wasnâ€™t actually saying that. Deceptively clipping and misleadingly describing a Trump comment about taxes A September 5 post from @KamalaHQ said, â€œTrump tells his wealthy donors he is going to make his tax handouts for the ultra-wealthy â€˜permanentâ€™ and cut their taxes â€˜even more.â€™â€ It included a 13-second clip of Trump saying, â€œThe fifth pillar of my plan is to make the Trump tax cuts permanent â€” they are massive tax cuts, biggest ever, permanent â€” and to cut taxes even more.â€ But the full video of the speech shows the @KamalaHQ post cut the video clip right before Trump elaborated on what he meant by cutting taxes â€œeven more.â€ The first two policies he mentioned were eliminating taxes on tips and eliminating taxes on Social Security benefits â€” policies that, whatever their merits or flaws, would certainly benefit people who are not wealthy. (So did his 2017 tax cuts, which produced gains on average for people of all income levels although the wealthy gained most.) Also, this was not a speech to wealthy Trump donors alone. It was a speech to the nonpartisan Economic Club of New York, whose members include a broad array of business executives from the area; some attendees were wealthy Trump donors, but others were not. The very next day, the Harris campaign used the @KamalaHQ account to tout her own popularity among chief executives. The Harris campaign defended the post in question in part by noting that wealthy Trump donors were in attendance and in part by saying that one of the biggest policy announcements Trump made in speech was that he plans to try to lower the corporate tax rate from 21% to 15% (a reduction Trump said would be â€œsolely for companies that make their product in Americaâ€). The Harris campaign said that â€œno tax on tips and Social Security were not new.â€ New or not, though, the @KamalaHQ clip clipped out those important words â€” making Trumpâ€™s comments on tax cuts sound more focused on the wealthy than they were. Cutting out critical words from a Vance comment about unions An August 29 post from @KamalaHQ said, â€œVance: Democrats want to attack Republicans as being anti-union and sometimes the shoe fits.â€ It included a five-second clip of Vance saying those words. But the full video of Vanceâ€™s speech to the International Association of Fire Fighters union shows that the Harris account clipped out the critical remark Vance made next, arguably in the very same sentence. His full comment: â€œA lot of Democrats want to attack Republicans as being anti-union and sometimes the shoe fits â€” but not me, and not Donald Trump.â€ He went on to outline actions he had taken to support firefighters. The Harris campaign said that this @KamalaHQ post was a â€œdirect quote of JD Vanceâ€; the campaign said the post is â€œclearly meant to convey that Vance acknowledges Republicans have a history of being anti-union.â€ But even â€œdirectâ€ quotes can be made misleading if they exclude the contextualizing words that came before or after the quote. If, for example, movie critic Sally Smith wrote, â€œThis director has a long history of making great films, but this one is awful,â€ it would be a â€œdirectâ€ quote if an ad for the new movie said, â€œSmith: â€˜This director has a long history of making great films.â€™â€ But that would also be deceptive. Falsely describing a comment from a Trump ally An August 28 post from @KamalaHQ said: â€œTrump operative on Project 2025: If you have principles without power, itâ€™s meaningless. We must wield power. We must seize power.â€ The post included a 12-second clip of far-right activist and Trump ally Jack Posobiec saying in an interview, â€œNow if you have all power and no principle youâ€™re a tyrant. But if you have principles without power, itâ€™s meaningless, itâ€™s completely meaningless. You must wield power. You must seize power.â€ But as Posobiec accurately noted in response to the @KamalaHQ post, he never even mentioned Project 2025 in these comments. The words Project 2025 do not appear at all in a transcript of the full interview. The Harris campaign defended the @KamalaHQ post with a confusing stretch â€” claiming Posobiecâ€™s comment is â€œpart ofâ€ a â€œlargerâ€ Trump-Project 2025 agenda to fire civil servants who are not seen as Trump loyalists. Posobiec wasnâ€™t talking here about firing civil servants, and, regardless, the post made a specific claim that Posobiec was talking about Project 2025, which he was not.

Title: September 14, 2024, presidential campaign news | CNN Politics
Content: Our live coverage has ended. Follow the latest 2024 election news here or read through the posts below. Vice President Kamala Harris warned Saturday that a second term for former President Donald Trump poses a â€œprofound threatâ€ to the vision of the nation. While delivering remarks at the Congressional Black Caucus Foundationâ€™s Phoenix Awards Dinner, Harris claimed Trump and his allies â€œintend to take our nation backward.â€   Harris railed against the former presidentâ€™s policies, criticizing his inability to outline his plans for health care during Tuesday nightâ€™s debate. She touted her plans to build intergenerational wealth, her economic agenda, and her determination to fight for reproductive freedoms, telling the CBC, â€œWhen you pass a bill to restore reproductive freedoms as President of the United States, I will proudly sign it into law.â€ Harris also emphasized the stakes of the election, telling attendees, â€œThe baton is in our hands.â€ ##Harris## President Joe Biden on Saturday slammed former President Donald Trump for his divisive rhetoric and conspiracy theories while praising Vice President Kamala Harris and telling Black Americans to â€œkeep the faith.â€ Speaking at the Congressional Black Caucus Foundationâ€™s Phoenix Awards, where he received a lifetime achievement award, Biden touted his legacy and looked ahead to the election. Biden specifically responded to the false rumor spread by the Trump campaign that Haitian immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, are stealing and eating peopleâ€™s pets. â€œHe says immigrants, Black and brown immigrants, poison the blood of our country. Right now, his running mate is attacking Haitian Americans in Ohio. Itâ€™s wrong,â€ Biden said. The president touted his accomplishments in lowering health care costs, his efforts to forgive student debt, his climate actions and his appointment of the first Black woman to the Supreme Court, Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson. Biden stressed that â€œwe have work to doâ€ in the limited time before the election. â€œSo, my challenge to you is to keep the faith. Do the work, because we know faith without works is dead,â€ he said. While introducing Harris, Biden called his vice president â€œthe best decision Iâ€™ve made.â€ Former President Donald Trump said Saturday that he would make up the lost tax revenue from his tax proposals with increased funds from drilling and by imposing tariffs on foreign nations. Trump has proposed eliminating taxes on tips, ending taxes on overtime pay and cutting income taxes on Social Security benefits. When asked in an interview with Las Vegas TV station KNTV how he plans to replace decreased revenue from the federal budget, Trump said, â€œDrill, baby drill.â€ Trump defended his tariffs plan when asked whether he believes the levies would cause prices to increase and wipe out any advantage from his tax proposals. Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz questioned why working-class voters might support former President Donald Trump during a rally in Superior, Wisconsin, on Saturday, while relating to fellow Democrats in exasperation over â€œfriends, neighbors, familyâ€ who support Trumpâ€™s policy proposals. The Democratic vice presidential nominee, whose brother and distant cousins have expressed support for Trump, laid out conversations heâ€™s had with voters about why they support the Republican nominee. Walzâ€™s comments come as the Harris campaign is aggressively courting independent and Republican-leaning voters in rural areas, including places like northwest Wisconsin, where the governor spoke Saturday. Walz also repeatedly stressed in his remarks the importance of bringing Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ message to Republican voters. His trip to Superior marks the end of his first solo swing through Michigan and Wisconsin as the Democratic vice presidential candidate. The town sits in a county President Joe Biden won by 9 points in 2020, but borders rural counties where the campaign is hoping to cut into Trumpâ€™s margins. Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance criticized the federal immigration parole program that allows Haitian immigrants to be in Springfield, Ohio, legally, arguing that â€œonly people who actually enrichâ€ the country should be here. Vanceâ€™s response was to a question about the potential backlash immigrants are facing after his recent false claims about Haitian migrants eating pets in Springfield. Local officials have repeatedly said there are no credible claims about such animal abuse, and following the evacuation of two schools and a bomb threat on the city hall, the cityâ€™s mayor urged former President Donald Trump and Vance â€œto pay attentionâ€ to the impact of their rhetoric. Vance on Saturday also criticized the Biden-Harris administrationâ€™s immigration policies, which include the immigration parole program that allows citizens and lawful residents to apply to have their family members from Haiti come to the US, according to the city of Springfieldâ€™s website. The city of Springfield notes on its website that approximately 12,000 to 15,000 immigrants live in Clark County. North Carolina Sen. Thom Tillis, Georgia Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene and South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham, who all condemned far-right agitator Laura Loomerâ€™s racist comments and expressed concern about her ties to former President Donald Trump, issued a joint statement Saturday saying they are glad â€œTrump has made clear he disavows Laura Loomerâ€™s offensive comments.â€ But at a Friday news conference, Trump didnâ€™t make it exactly clear he condemns Loomerâ€™s comments. In response to questions about Loomerâ€™s racist and conspiratorial statements, Trump said that he had just heard about them and that Loomer was a person with â€œstrong opinions.â€ â€œI do know that she may have said something based on what youâ€™re telling me, but I donâ€™t know what she said, but Iâ€™ll go take a look and Iâ€™ll put out a statement later on,â€ Trump said.  When asked by CNNâ€™s Kristen Holmes about his allies expressing concerns, Trump said, â€œLauraâ€™s been a supporter of mine, just like a lot of people are supporters, and sheâ€™s been a supporter of mine. She speaks very positively of the campaign. â€¦ I donâ€™t control Laura. Laura has to say what she wants. Sheâ€™s a free spirit.â€ Later on Truth Social, Trump said he disagreed â€œwith the statementsâ€ Loomer made but didnâ€™t specify which statements.  Vice President Kamala Harris told donors at a fundraiser in Washington, DC, on Saturday that the contrast with former President Donald Trump was â€œvery clearâ€ on the debate stage this week. In the days following the debate, Harris has repeatedly blasted the former president for his performance. She criticized him Saturday for having â€œno plan for how he would address the needs of the American peopleâ€ before hitting him on policy issues including his promise to replace the Affordable Care Act without offering a plan to do so. â€œSo heâ€™s saying that again, that he wants to replace it. And then remember what he said about how heâ€™s going to do it? You guys watched the debate. Concepts of a plan. Thatâ€™s right. Concepts of a plan. No actual plan,â€ she said. Harris reminded donors of the stakes of the election, telling them the â€œclock is tickingâ€ with only 52 days until Election Day and urging them to volunteer and mobilize their friends to vote.  Donald Trump said Saturday that Springfield, Ohio, has â€œbeen taken over by illegal migrants,â€ and that he doesnâ€™t know about the bomb threats the town has been receiving since he and other Republicans spread false claims about Haitian immigrants eating pets there. Some context: The claim went viral a few weeks ago and has been promoted by prominent national-level Republicans, including Trump and his running mate, Ohio Sen. JD Vance. Local officials have repeatedly tried to end the rumor, and the city has said there are no credible reports of animal abuse â€œby individuals within the immigrant community.â€ As CNN reported, Springfield City Hall was forced to close due to a bomb threat on Thursday. Two elementary schools were also evacuated Friday â€œbased on information received from the Springfield Police Division,â€ the cityâ€™s school district said. Trump said Friday that the â€œreal threat is whatâ€™s happening at our borderâ€ rather than the bomb threats in Springfield.  The city notes on its website that approximately 12,000 to 15,000 immigrants live in Clark County, and that Haitian immigrants are there legally as part of a parole program that allows citizens and lawful residents to apply to have their family members from Haiti come to the US. Trumpâ€™s remarks Saturday were the latest in a string of inflammatory rhetoric about immigrants this week. Republican vice presidential nominee JD Vance stopped by Sup Dog, a bar in downtown Greenville, North Carolina, ahead of the East Carolina v. Appalachian State football game, which Vance is attending. With music blasting on the outdoor patio, the Ohio senator walked up with a drink in his hand and sat down at a picnic table with three young men. Vance, who was joined by his wife, Usha, made his way to different tables, greeting people, chatting and taking photos.  â€œRemember to vote November, right,â€ Vance told a group of people. â€œYâ€™all going to the game or are you just here to drink?â€ One of the men asked, â€œAny chance you want to get drinks at the bar?â€ Vance laughed and said he already had one. â€œIf I take shots all of these reporters will cover it negatively, so I canâ€™t do it,â€ Vance joked. Pigskin politics: Last week, the Democratic National Committee flew planes over college football games in Midwestern battleground states featuring banners linking Vance and his running mate, former President Donald Trump, to the controversial conservative policy platform Project 2025. Trump has previously enjoyed warm welcomes at red state college games. Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ campaign and Nebraska Democratic officials are keeping a close eye on any last-minute efforts to change the election law that awards the stateâ€™s electoral votes by congressional district, rather than statewide winner. Nebraskaâ€™s unique law presents an opportunity for Democrats to secure one of the stateâ€™s votes by winning the district surrounding Omaha â€” a critical blue dot in a sea of red. The stateâ€™s Republican Gov. Jim Pillen made it clear Friday that he is willing to call a special legislative session on changing the state to a â€œwinner takes allâ€ model before the November election â€” but said in a statement that he doesnâ€™t yet have â€œconcrete and public indicationâ€ that enough lawmakers would back the move. Nebraska Democratic chairwoman Jane Kleeb said Saturday that Pillenâ€™s statement signals Republicans â€œdo not have the votes to change the fair electoral system we have in Nebraska.â€ When the matter of changing the law came up for a vote in the state legislature earlier this year, it was 17 votes shy of passing. Kleeb said Saturday that those 17 votes remain â€œvery solid.â€ Why this is so important: If Vice President Kamala Harris can win the â€œblue wallâ€ states of Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania, plus the blue dot vote in Nebraska, she can likely reach 270 electoral votes without winning a single other contested battleground state. Prominent GOP backer: Conservative activist Charlie Kirk, who has led a rallying cry in favor of changing the election law, is returning to the state Saturday to appear at a GOP tailgate party before a Nebraska football game. Kleeb dismissed Kirkâ€™s involvement in the state as â€œbullying and bluster.â€ Democratic vice presidential nominee Tim Walz made a direct pitch to Muslim and Arab American voters in Michigan, addressing those concerned about the Biden administrationâ€™s handling of the war in Gaza. The Minnesota governor used an interview Friday to reiterate Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ support for a ceasefire-hostage deal between Israel and Hamas, and argued Trumpâ€™s record of targeting Muslim Americans is â€œnot in your best interest.â€ Harris is more cognizant of the suffering of Palestinians than Trump, Walz said in the interview with WXMI in Grand Rapids, Michigan, addressing those from the â€œAbandon Harrisâ€ movement. Illustrating the constant balancing act for the Democratic ticket on the Middle East, Walz also emphasized the importance of Israelâ€™s self-defense. â€œThatâ€™s why sheâ€™s the person to move us toward a two-state solution, where Israel can be protected, we get our hostages back, and Gaza can be self-determined,â€ he added. Walz contrasted Harrisâ€™ view with Trumpâ€™s previous support of a travel ban that targeted people from Muslim-majority countries, and his calls to send some Muslim members of Congress to their countries of origin. â€œDonald Trump is offering you nothing,â€ Walz said, to voters skeptical of Harris over the issue. â€œThat is not in your best interest.â€ A social media account run by Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ campaign has been repeatedly deceptive. The campaign deploys the @KamalaHQ account as a kind of irreverent attack dog, using jocular posts to draw attention to controversial, incorrect or dubious comments by Trump and his allies. But the account, which the Harris campaign calls its â€œofficial rapid response page,â€ has itself made inaccurate comments on multiple occasions. In one example, an August 17 post from @KamalaHQ strongly suggested Trump had gotten confused about what state he was in during an event in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. The post said, â€œTrump: Would that be okay, North Carolina? (He is in Pennsylvania).â€ It included a six-second video clip in which Trump said, while pointing to his left, â€œWould that be OK, North Carolina? I donâ€™t think so, right.â€ The Harris campaign was explicit about its intentions in the version of the post it made on the Instagram @KamalaHQ account, saying, â€œDonald Trump is lost and confused.â€ But Trump was not lost or confused. The full video of the rally shows that earlier in the speech he had pointed to the same part of the crowd to acknowledge a group of ardent supporters from North Carolina. Later, in the moment shown by @KamalaHQ, he pointed to these supporters again and referred to them as â€œNorth Carolina.â€ On Thursday, the @KamalaHQ account made a new attempt to suggest that Trump was confused about his location, but again left out key context. Read about that post and six more examples in the full fact check. Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz will make campaign stops in Georgia and North Carolina on Tuesday, Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ campaign announced Saturday.  The Democratic vice presidential nominee will speak at an event in Macon, Georgia, in the morning before making stops in Atlanta later in the day, the campaign said. In the evening heâ€™ll fly to Asheville, North Carolina, where heâ€™ll speak at a campaign rally.  The trip marks Walzâ€™s first solo visit to Georgia and his second solo trip to North Carolina since becoming Harrisâ€™ running mate. Both states are among the key battlegrounds expected to determine the 2024 presidential election. Democratic Rep. Sheila Cherfilus-McCormick on Saturday condemned former President Donald Trumpâ€™s false claims about Haitian immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, and warned that his rhetoric could spark violence against immigrants.  â€œMy first reaction was just pure disgust and disdain,â€ the Florida congresswoman and House Haiti Caucus co-chair said Saturday on CNNâ€™s â€œFirst of All with Victor Blackwell.â€ â€œFor him to say that theyâ€™re actually committing crimes and stealing pets is a big lie.â€  Cherfilus-McCormick is the only Haitian American currently serving in Congress and says sheâ€™s â€œabsolutelyâ€ concerned that immigrants will get hurt if Trump continues with this inflammatory message. â€œWeâ€™re feeling the combativeness, weâ€™re feeling the death threats,â€ the lawmaker said, adding that sheâ€™s â€œhearing that from people all across the country.â€ Remember: Trump and his running mate, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, continue to promote false claims that Haitian immigrants are killing and eating pets in Springfield, Ohio. The rumor appears to have started on a local Facebook group for the community, which has seen an influx of as many as 20,000 Haitian immigrants under the Immigration Parole Program, and has been amplified by right-wing voices as part of their broader anti-immigrant messaging. At a rally Friday, Trump ramped up his rhetoric about immigrants, also doubling down on false claims that Venezuelan gangs were â€œtaking overâ€ Aurora, Colorado.  CNNâ€™s Omar Jimenez contributed reporting to this post. Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ campaign is launching a wave of new efforts targeting Latino voters during Hispanic Heritage Month to mobilize the key demographic in battleground states. Part of its outreach includes a $3 million investment into Spanish-language radio for September, which the campaign said is among the largest investments into Hispanic media ever. The investment consists of engagements with influential radio personalities, sports-themed creative and advertising during local baseball, football, and soccer team coverage.  The campaign also released a new ad on Friday titled, â€œMy Voice,â€ featuring Victor Martinez, an Allentown, Pennsylvania-based Lehigh Valley host of La Mega Radio who highlighted Harrisâ€™ efforts to lower costs for Latino working families. Throughout the month, surrogates will be deployed to events, including Saturday nightâ€™s fight between world champion boxer Canelo Alvarez and Edgar Berlanga, Mexican Independence Day celebrations, and the Detroit Tigers Hispanic Heritage Tailgate. Additionally, organizers will focus on an aggressive push of bilingual phone banking, in-person organizing events and training to help reach the constituency.  Harris is also set to deliver remarks at the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Instituteâ€™s annual conference on Wednesday. Republicans havenâ€™t given up on turning Nebraskaâ€™s blue dot red. Republican Gov. Jim Pillen said in a statement Friday that heâ€™s prepared to call a special session of the Nebraska legislature before the November election to change the state law that awards electoral votes by congressional district, rather than awarding all of them to the statewide winner. But, Pillen said, he would only do so if there was sufficient support from state lawmakers. Pillenâ€™s statement underscores his willingness to change state law â€” an extraordinary move, given the election is less than two months away â€” but only if Republicans could persuade 33 senators to change their mind and support the bill. So far, support for a switch to the â€œwinner takes allâ€ format has been a few votes short. Key context: Omahaâ€™s blue dot refers to Nebraskaâ€™s 2nd Congressional District and its single electoral vote, which is considered competitive for Democrats in the otherwise red state, thanks to the current system of awarding electoral votes proportionally. If Vice President Kamala Harris can win the â€œblue wallâ€ states of Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania, plus the blue dot, she can reach 270 electoral votes without winning a single other contested battleground state. Nebraska and Maine are the only two states that award electoral votes by congressional district, rather than by statewide winner. Barack Obama in 2008 and Joe Biden in 2020 are the Democratic Partyâ€™s only two candidates to reap a single electoral vote reward. The effort to change the law now signals concern by Republicans that Trump is struggling to win the district. The Harris campaign is spending millions to win there. Signs with a blue dot have been appearing on yards across Omaha in recent weeks. Hereâ€™s a look at what the 2024 presidential campaigns are up to on Saturday: Harris: Vice President Kamala Harris is scheduled to make remarks this afternoon at a fundraiser in Washington, DC, that will not be open the media. Harris is then expected to attend the Congressional Black Caucus Foundationâ€™s Phoenix Award Gala dinner in DC on Saturday evening, where she and President Joe Biden will deliver remarks. Second gentleman Doug Emhoff is also expected to attend. Harrisâ€™ running mate, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, will speak this afternoon at a campaign rally in Superior, Wisconsin.   Trump: Former President Donald Trump remains in Nevada for an event today in Las Vegas. His running mate Sen. JD Vance is expected to attend the Appalachian State vs. East Carolina college football game in Greenville, North Carolina, which kicks off at 4 p.m. ET. Former President Donald Trump said at a rally Friday that if heâ€™s reelected, he will deploy federal law enforcement officials to â€œliberate parts of our country,â€ as he continued to claim without evidence that Venezuelan gangs were taking over parts of Colorado. Trumpâ€™s comments were part of a series of remarks this week ramping up his rhetoric and stoking fears about both undocumented immigrants and migrants who have entered the country legally. Trump said he would launch a special task force to address organized crime and foreign gangs, which he said are â€œconqueringâ€ the country. Some context: Trump was referencing rumors that Venezuelan gangs are â€œtaking overâ€ buildings in Aurora, Colorado, which have been amplified by Republicans as another flashpoint in the debate over immigration. Police in the Colorado community say Venezuelan gangs are present there, but their influence is â€œisolatedâ€ and has been â€œoverstated.â€ Hereâ€™s a closer look at whatâ€™s going on in Aurora. More from Trump: The former president also claimed without evidence that armed undocumented immigrants are â€œtaking over our country from within.â€ Trump also used the rally to further amplify debunked social media rumors about Haitian migrants in Ohio eating pets. Former President Donald Trump on Friday promoted a baseless claim circulating on right-wing social media that Kamala Harris wore an earpiece at Tuesdayâ€™s ABC presidential debate and again baselessly suggested that the vice president received the debate questions in advance.  The conspiracy theory about the earpiece has been promoted by far-right agitator Laura Loomer, who has traveled with Trump in recent days. â€œInteresting choice of earrings tonight, @KamalaHarrisâ€¦â€ Loomer posted Wednesday on social media, including a screenshot of an article about â€œaudio earrings.â€ As CNN previously reported, several people close to Trump say Loomer has contributed to some of the unseemly conspiracy theories the former president has elevated since Harris replaced Biden on the ticket. Trump has repeatedly claimed that the ABC debate was â€œrigged,â€ and he has previously baselessly suggested that Harris was provided the questions in advance. The former president said this week that he wonâ€™t participate in another debate, while Harris has called for another face-off. Trump suggested Friday, though, that he may change his mind about another debate. President Joe Biden criticized former President Donald Trumpâ€™s recent disparagement of Haitian migrants during a Black Excellence brunch hosted at the White House on Friday.  Biden condemned the false claim promoted by Trump at this weekâ€™s presidential debate that Haitian immigrants are stealing and eating other peopleâ€™s pets in Springfield, Ohio. Other high-level Republicans, including vice presidential candidate Sen. JD Vance, have propagated the lie. Trumpâ€™s debunked claims: Trump has pledged â€œlarge deportationsâ€ from Springfield, which has become a political flashpoint as Republicans spread the false claims about migrants in the Ohio community. Springfield has had an influx of as many as 20,000 Haitian immigrants, who are in the US legally under the Immigration Parole Program. The unsubstantiated claims about animals being harmed in the community appear to be the result of an unwieldy game of telephone that began as a rumor in a local Facebook group before spiraling to reach the highest echelons of conservative media and the Republican Party. City officials have said there are no credible or specific claims of pets being harmed by immigrants in the community. Vice President Kamala Harris on Friday continued to draw contrasts with former President Donald Trump as she seized on post-debate momentum in Pennsylvania.  Harris again slammed his debate performance, calling it a â€œtired playbook,â€ while claiming he failed to address the needs of Americans. â€œWell, folks, itâ€™s time to turn the page. Letâ€™s turn the pageâ€¦ And we are not going back, because America is ready for a new way forward,â€ she said. The vice president stressed the importance of small businesses and she repeatedly hit her opponent on his economic agenda, including attacking Trump for suggesting he only has â€œconcepts of a planâ€ to end the Affordable Care Act, but not laying out how he would replace it. While touting her economic own plan, Harris also focused part of her message on job opportunities that donâ€™t require 4-year degrees. Harrisâ€™ visited Johnstown and Wilkes-Barre on Friday, both in counties that Trump won in 2016 and 2020.

Title: How a false rumor about pets in Ohio and Laura Loomerâ€™s presence helped derail Trumpâ€™s planned attacks on Harris | CNN Politics
Content: Donald Trump wanted to spend this week attacking one of Democratic rival Kamala Harrisâ€™ biggest political vulnerabilities. Instead, he spent most of the week falsely claiming that migrants are eating pets in a small town in Ohio and defending his embrace of a far-right agitator whose presence is causing concern among his allies. Trumpâ€™s repeated parroting of unfounded social media rumors about Haitian migrants in Ohio eating pets stole headlines during a trip West, including stops in Arizona and Nevada, late this week. The promotion of the claims overshadowed a series of speeches aimed at the economy and blaming Harris for border security failures. Trump, in a news conference in California on Friday, promised â€œlarge deportationsâ€ from Springfield, Ohio â€” the town that has become a political flashpoint as Republicans, including Trump and his running mate, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, spread false claims about Haitian immigrants eating pets. The city of Springfield notes on its website that approximately 12,000 to 15,000 immigrants live in Clark County, and that Haitian immigrants are there legally as part of a parole program that allows citizens and lawful residents to apply to have their family members from Haiti come to the United States. Trump also pointed to a Venezuelan gang in Aurora, Colorado. Continuing to use dehumanizing language to describe undocumented immigrants, Trump said â€œnests of bad peopleâ€ are being emptied into the United States. â€œItâ€™s like an invasion from within, and weâ€™re going to have the largest deportation in the history of our country. And weâ€™re going to start with Springfield and Aurora.â€ â€œThe people of Ohio are scared,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s going to get worse. Itâ€™s going to get so bad. You know what weâ€™re experiencing now is theyâ€™re just getting settled in.â€ Trump reiterated the same themes later Friday at a rally in Las Vegas. â€œWe are under invasion just like it was an army, except in many ways itâ€™s more difficult because they donâ€™t wear a uniform, you donâ€™t know who the hell to go after,â€ he said. Again bringing up both Springfield and Aurora, Trump continued, â€œI am your border president. From now on I want to be your border president.â€ Republicans broadly believe that immigration and border security are a top political issue for the party â€” and one they can use to hammer Harris, who they have labeled President Joe Bidenâ€™s â€œborder czar.â€ That label stems from Biden asking the vice president in 2021 to lead diplomacy with El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras to address the conditions that prompted their citizens to try to migrate to the United States. However, during Tuesdayâ€™s debate, Trumpâ€™s attacks on Harris over immigration veered into the outrageous, as he falsely claimed that migrants are eating dogs and cats in Springfield. Trumpâ€™s remarks were met with a sharp condemnation from Biden. â€œItâ€™s simply wrong. And thereâ€™s no place in America. This has to stop â€” what heâ€™s doing â€” has to stop,â€ Biden said during a Black Excellence Brunch hosted at the White House on Friday. The city hall in Springfield was forced to close due to a bomb threat on Thursday. Two elementary schools were evacuated Friday â€œbased on information received from the Springfield Police Division,â€ the Springfield City School District announced Friday. Two local hospitals â€” Kettering Health and Mercy Health Springfield Regional Medical Center â€” were also forced into lockdown due to bomb threats Saturday, according to statements sent to CNN. Springfield police said they received two calls Saturday about a Proud Boys presence in the city. A video circulating on social media shows a group of approximately 15 to 20 individuals, some of whom are carrying flags and wearing clothing with logos associated with the far-right Proud Boys, marching in the city. Police told CNN that when officers went to the area, the group was no longer there. Springfield Mayor Rob Rue on Thursday night urged national candidates â€” a clear reference to Trump and Vance â€” to â€œpay attention to what their words are doing to cities like ours.â€ â€œWe need help, not hate,â€ Rue said. Trump dismissed those concerns on Friday, and again on Saturday when asked whether he denounced the threats in Springfield. â€œI donâ€™t know what happened with the, uh, bomb threats,â€ Trump said during a visit to the Las Vegas Police Protective Association on Saturday. â€œI know that (Springfield has) been taken over by illegal migrants, and thatâ€™s a terrible thing that happened.â€ Even Pope Francis on Friday sharply criticized Trump over his position on immigration, while also lambasting Harris for her support for abortion rights. â€œTo send migrants away, to leave them wherever you want, to leave them â€¦ itâ€™s something terrible, there is evil there. To send away a child from the womb of the mother is an assassination, because there is life. We must speak about these things clearly,â€ the pope said. Vance, Trumpâ€™s running mate, argued that Trumpâ€™s comments ignited conversation about immigration â€” even as he acknowledged on X the flimsiness of the rumors that ignited the story. On Tuesday, Vance posted, â€œItâ€™s possible, of course, that all of these rumors will turn out to be false.â€ But the veracity of the claims did not seem to be his top concern. â€œDonâ€™t let biased media shame you into not discussing this slow moving humanitarian crisis in a small Ohio town. We should talk about it every single day. Kamala Harris did this. And sheâ€™ll keep doing it unless we stop her,â€ he posted on X on Friday. The claim of pets being eaten in Ohio was not the only eyebrow raising moment from this week that has put the focus on the former presidentâ€™s campaign. Trump has been spending time with far-right agitator Laura Loomer, who has spread conspiracy theories about the September 11, 2001, terrorist attack and shared racist comments on social media attacking Harris. Several people close to the former president say Loomer has contributed to some of the unseemly conspiracy theories Trump has elevated since Harris replaced Biden on the ticket, a change that has left the GOP nominee increasingly unsettled by the political landscape he now faces. Trump on Friday described Loomer as a â€œfree spiritâ€ and â€œsupporter.â€ â€œSheâ€™s a strong person. Sheâ€™s got strong opinions, and I donâ€™t know what she said, but thatâ€™s not up to me. Sheâ€™s a supporter,â€ Trump said. Democratic National Committee rapid response director Alex Floyd on Friday highlighted Trumpâ€™s relationship with Loomer and other controversial allies. He said those surrounding Trump are â€œas professional as youâ€™d expect for a convicted fraudster.â€ Trump and Harris were back on the campaign trail late this week after a Tuesday night debate that 63% of viewers said Harris won over Trumpâ€™s 37%, according to a CNN poll of debate watchers conducted by SSRS.  The former presidentâ€™s trip West came as Harris campaigned in Pennsylvania â€” the largest battleground of the 2024 election, with 19 Electoral College votes up for grabs. Combined, the commonwealth has already seen $175 million spent on television ads â€” more than $93 million by Democrats and more than $81 million by Republicans, according to AdImpact data. Another $136 million, including nearly $77 million by Democrats and $59 million by Republicans, has been booked between Saturday and Election Day. Thatâ€™s more than has been spent, or reserved, in any other state. Harris needs strong turnout in Democratic strongholds such as Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, but also to minimize Trumpâ€™s margins as much as possible in red parts of the state. Her visit Friday focused on two counties Trump won during both of his White House bids â€” Cambria and Luzerne. â€œUltimately, I feel very strongly that we have to earn every vote and that means spending time with folks in the community where they live. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m here. Weâ€™re going to be spending a lot more time in Pennsylvania,â€ Harris told reporters at a bookstore in Johnstown on Friday. This story has been updated with additional developments.

Title: Georgia Lt. Gov. Burt Jones wonâ€™t be charged in Trump election subversion case, prosecutor says | CNN Politics
Content: The special prosecutor appointed to investigate Georgia Lt. Gov. Burt Jonesâ€™ role as a fake elector after the 2020 election announced he will not move forward with criminal charges against the former state senator. Jones is one of 16 Republican fake Trump electors who signed on to the â€œunofficial electorate certificateâ€ at Georgiaâ€™s state capital in December 2020 in a plan to subvert the Electoral College after that yearâ€™s presidential election. Jones had been a target of Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis in her investigation that led to a sprawling racketeering election subversion case against former President Donald Trump and several of his allies. â€œMy review of the evidence finds this matter does not warrant further consideration,â€ Pete Skandalakis, executive director of a bipartisan group that oversees all prosecutors in Georgia, said in a written statement on Friday. â€œThe evidence reveals Senator Jones acted in a manner consistent with his position representing the concerns of his constituents and in reliance upon the advice of attorneys when he served as an alternate elector,â€ Skandalakis wrote. â€œThe evidence also indicates Senator Jones did not act with criminal intent, which is an essential element of committing any crime.â€ A Georgia judge blocked Willis from investigating Jones in July 2022. Jones was then a Republican state senator, and Willis was reprimanded by the judge for hosting a fundraiser for the Democratic candidate who was running against Jones to be Georgiaâ€™s next lieutenant governor. In his four-page written statement on Friday, Skandalakis said that Jones â€œfully cooperatedâ€ with the lengthy investigation over the course of four interviews. The prosecutor said he examined the evidence and Jonesâ€™ motives, noting Jones called for a special session in Georgiaâ€™s General Assembly after the 2020 election to investigate complaints made by constituents. Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, declined to hold a special session to overturn the results. In his statement, Skandalakis said Jones â€œunderstands he is subject to a witness subpoena and may be called to testify at any pending federal or state trial.â€ â€œI have always wanted to tell my story in front of a fair and unbiased prosecutor, â€œLt. Gov Burt Jones told CNN in a written statement. â€œI look forward to being able to focus on the work I was elected to do.â€ Willisâ€™ office told CNN that it canâ€™t comment on the decision.

Title: Pope Francis criticizes Trump and Harris, says voters must choose between â€˜lesser of two evilsâ€™ | CNN Politics
Content: Pope Francis on Friday described the choice US voters must make in the presidential election as one between the â€œlesser of two evils,â€ deeming former President Donald Trumpâ€™s anti-migrant policies and Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ support of abortion rights as both being â€œagainst life.â€ â€œOne must choose the lesser of two evils. Who is the lesser of two evils? That lady or that gentleman? I donâ€™t know,â€ Francis said during a press conference on the papal plane, referring to Harris and Trump. â€œEveryone with a conscience should think on this and do it.â€ Francis has been more vocal about politics than his predecessors and has moved to make the Catholic Church more open. While he has consistently and strongly defended the Catholic Churchâ€™s teaching that abortion is the deliberate destruction of a human life, Francis has also insisted it cannot be isolated from other issues concerning human life, including immigration. â€œTo send migrants away, to leave them wherever you want, to leave them â€¦ itâ€™s something terrible, there is evil there. To send away a child from the womb of the mother is an assassination, because there is life. We must speak about these things clearly,â€ he said. Francis has previously weighed in on political issues, signaling more progressive stances by allowing priests to forgive abortions, authorizing blessings for same-sex couples and repeatedly warning about climate change. He has challenged Catholic bishops in the US who have insisted that abortion is the â€œpre-eminentâ€ issue, arguing that the plight of migrants is also about the defense of life. In 2016, Francis described then-presidential candidate Trumpâ€™s plan to build a wall to stop migrants from crossing the US-Mexico border as â€œnot Christian.â€ And when bishops were debating in 2021 whether to deny communion to public figures who support abortion rights, including President Joe Biden, Francis urged them to make their decisions from a â€œpastoralâ€ viewpoint and not a political one. The pope has said he has never denied communion to anyone. Francis has criticized couples who choose to have pets rather than children, aligning with views expressed by Trumpâ€™s running mate, Sen. JD Vance, a converted Catholic who has derided women without kids as â€œchildless cat ladiesâ€ and described those in the countryâ€™s â€œleadership classâ€ who donâ€™t have children as â€œmore sociopathic.â€ US Catholics also have a range of views. According to Pew Research, 52% of Catholic registered voters describe themselves as being or leaning Republican, while 44% say they are or lean Democrat. Catholic voters were split in 2020, with 50% voting for Biden and 49% supporting Trump, according to Pew. But a majority of Catholics â€“ 61% â€“ believe abortion should be legal in all or most cases. This story has been updated with additional reporting.

Title: GOP-aligned group airs antisemitic ads in Michigan featuring Doug Emhoff and highlighting Harrisâ€™ Jewish ties | CNN Politics
Content: A super PAC with Republican ties is running digital ads in Michigan promoting the Jewish faith of Kamala Harrisâ€™s husband and touting the vice presidentâ€™s support for Israel in an apparent play to undercut Harris with the battleground stateâ€™s large Arab American population amid ongoing political fallout over the war in Gaza. Future Coalition PAC has spent nearly $60,000 running several YouTube ads targeting Michigan, according to Googleâ€™s Ads Transparency Center. Each of the ads emphatically states Harrisâ€™ support for Israel, and many pointedly highlight her husband, Doug Emhoff, who is Jewish. The ads are replete with images of the Israeli flag, and multiple spots refer to Emhoff as Harrisâ€™ â€œtop adviser,â€ playing into antisemitic tropes that American Jews have dual loyalties to the US and Israel. The ads appear aimed at stoking divisions within the Democratic coalition that have been exacerbated in the wake of the Hamas-led October 7 attack on Israel and Israelâ€™s ongoing military operations in Gaza. Anger among the Democratic Partyâ€™s pro-Palestinian factions over the Biden administrationâ€™s continued support for Israelâ€™s military operation in Gaza has led to demonstrations around the country calling for an immediate ceasefire. And the issue is especially relevant in battleground Michigan, where Arab and Muslim Americans, many sympathetic to the Palestinian cause, make up a substantial voting bloc. In 2020, nearly 146,000 Muslim Americans voted in the general election in Michigan, according to an analysis by Emgage, a group working to grow Muslim Americansâ€™ political power. Joe Biden won the state by 150,000 votes four years ago. Polls have shown a close contest this year between Harris and former President Donald Trump. One of the Future Coalition ads homes in on Emhoff, including depicting images of the second gentleman wearing a yarmulke and of him visiting the Auschwitz concentration camp. â€œKamala Harris is a strong leader for these difficult times. And joining Kamala will be her husband and top adviser, Doug Emhoff. Doug Emhoff, who would be the first Jewish presidential spouse ever. Kamala Harris and Doug Emhoff: making history, standing up for whatâ€™s right, supporting Israel.â€ Another one of the ads opens, â€œVice President Harris has chosen a side, the right side. Harris has made herself clear: She stands with Israel and the Jewish people. She has, again and again. She understands the unbreakable bond between the US and Israel.â€ The ad continues, â€œSo when (Israeli leader Benjamin) Netanyahu came to DC, Harris hosted the prime minister at the White House. And when supporters of a free Palestine stood up for Gaza, Harris put them in their place. And supporters of free Palestine? They hate her. Because Kamala Harris gets it. We can trust sheâ€™ll always support Israel.â€ Other ads from the group contain similar themes. â€œThis November, letâ€™s make history. Together, we will put a real pro-Israel president in the White House. And joining Kamala will be her husband and top advisor, Doug Emhoff, who would be the first Jewish presidential spouse ever. Only in America: Kamala Harris and Doug Emhoff.â€ Formed earlier this month, Future Coalition PAC has not yet filed a report detailing its donors or fundraising with the Federal Election Commission. Other filings by the group, however, suggest its GOP links: The group lists as its assistant treasurer Cabell Hobbs, who served as the treasurer for a super PAC supporting Florida Gov. Ron DeSantisâ€™ 2024 presidential bid. CNN has reached out to the PAC for comment. This story and headline have been updated.

Title: September 13, 2024, presidential campaign news | CNN Politics
Content: Our live coverage has ended. Follow the latest 2024 election news or read through the posts below. Former President Donald Trump on Friday promoted a baseless claim circulating on right-wing social media that Kamala Harris wore an earpiece at Tuesdayâ€™s ABC presidential debate and again baselessly suggested that the vice president received the debate questions in advance.  The conspiracy theory about the earpiece has been promoted by far-right agitator Laura Loomer, who has traveled with Trump in recent days. â€œInteresting choice of earrings tonight, @KamalaHarrisâ€¦â€ Loomer posted Wednesday on social media, including a screenshot of an article about â€œaudio earrings.â€ As CNN previously reported, several people close to Trump say Loomer has contributed to some of the unseemly conspiracy theories the former president has elevated since Harris replaced Biden on the ticket. Trump has repeatedly claimed that the ABC debate was â€œrigged,â€ and he has previously baselessly suggested that Harris was provided the questions in advance. The former president said this week that he wonâ€™t participate in another debate, while Harris has called for another face-off. Trump suggested Friday, though, that he may change his mind about another debate. New Hampshire Gov.
