Pete Buttigieg on Thursday slammed former President Donald Trumpâ€™s recent false claims that migrants are eating pets, saying itâ€™s a strategy to distract from the Republican presidential nomineeâ€™s record. In recent days, Trump and his allies, including running mate JD Vance, have promoted false claims that Haitian migrants in Ohio are killing and eating family pets. Trump repeated the conspiracy theory during the ABC presidential debate Tuesday night, although the City of Springfield and the local police have said theyâ€™ve seen no evidence for the claim. Buttigieg, who spoke in his personal capacity but serves as transportation secretary in the Biden administration, said that while he thinks it is a distraction technique, â€œit contributes to this bigger picture of demonizing immigrants.â€ Buttigieg praised Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ debate performance but stressed that groundwork and organizing is more important to win the race. Election Day is less than two months away, and both Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump have a busy schedule of campaign events today following their presidential debate. Trump said he would not participate in a third debate, while the vice presidentâ€™s campaign called for another one following Tuesday nightâ€™s event on ABC. Hereâ€™s more on the campaign:

Title: How Harris aims to keep drawing eyeballs as the hard campaigning begins | CNN Politics
Content: At a leadership retreat for top aides in Wilmington last week, Jen Oâ€™Malley Dillon â€“ the campaign chair hired by Joe Biden and retained by Kamala Harris â€“ ticked through the battleground states and warned them: the vice president still did not have any one sure path to 270 electoral votes. Pennsylvania looks rough, though very possible, by their internal numbers before the debate. North Carolina, disappointing Democrats every election for the last 15 years, is feeling better to them this time around than Arizona, which Biden narrowly won four years ago. Nevada and Georgia both seem possible, though depending on the poll, can take a lot of squinting. Michigan and Wisconsin are looking like the best of the bunch for Harris, according to the campaignâ€™s internal numbers. As pumped as Harris aides are about her debate performance earlier this week, they donâ€™t think it changed any of that. That makes for a lot of potential paths to victory based on the current and projected internal data, Oâ€™Malley Dillon told them last week, but multiple top aides on the Harris campaign told CNN they fear that if the election were held next Tuesday instead of eight Tuesdays from now, Trump still would be in a good position to win. After two and a half slower weeks since she closed out her convention in Chicago, a number of leading Democrats are stressing out that Harris could be in danger of losing the excitement and good vibes they need to overpower what they expect to be high and devoted turnout for Trump. But that is not the feeling in Harris campaign headquarters, where many conversations focus on the 5-6% of voters still showing up undecided in battleground states, the set opinions those voters have of Trump and the continuing interest they tend to say they have in learning more about Harris. Top aides tend to talk these days about â€œeyeballsâ€ and â€œmoments,â€ and however many different plays they can come up with. They will keep having Harris at big rallies, but slip smaller events in between, building out the affinity groups and leaning into targeted appeals like playing up the endorsement from former GOP Rep. Liz Cheney. Harrisâ€™ appearance with the National Association of Black Journalists next week, for example, scheduled for Philadelphia on National Voter Registration Day, was a very orchestrated choice. â€œThereâ€™s a quiet confidence and security in what weâ€™re doing and the mission, but no one thinks we have this in the bag,â€ said a Harris campaign aide. â€œItâ€™s going to be a grind until Election Day, and after.â€ Harris advisers are spending their days cutting campaign ads from the debate and poring through data that they believe may show she got an important sliver of a bump. An internal summary of the campaignâ€™s â€œdial groupsâ€ measuring immediate reactions, which was described to CNN, says that Harrisâ€™ best rated moment was when she spoke about abortion and Trumpâ€™s worst rated moment was when he cited a fake story about immigrants eating pets. But a dozen leading Democratic operatives and officials told CNN they worry what will happen if the campaign reverts, as it has done this week after the debate, to the standard rhythm of bus tours and stump speeches and teases of an unconventional interview or two. Some Democratic officials have been wishfully scrolling through Taylor Swiftâ€™s Eras Tour schedule â€“ which features three shows each in Miami, New Orleans and Indianapolis in the lead up to the election â€” and have begun reach out to try to get Swift to translate her endorsement into campaign concerts. The dream scenario in the minds of several of the people talking about this: either joint or parallel Swift appearances with BeyoncÃ©. Harris has â€œbecome a cultural political icon â€” politics is too small to hold it. Youâ€™ve got to do something that transcends it,â€ said one top Democratic official trying to make the shows happen. â€œAn unconventional campaign means you have to do unconventional things.â€ At campaign headquarters, aides are already working toward more appearances like Harrisâ€™ online conversation next week with Oprah Winfrey instead of any big speeches or more policy rollouts like her economic plans, unless the campaign sees ways to leverage those into grabbing more attention. Yet Harris advisers are running into limits of the calendar: unless they succeed in goading Trump into accepting a second debate, the only big event left before Election Day is the Tim Walz-JD Vance vice presidential debate on October 1. David Plouffe, former President Barack Obamaâ€™s campaign manager, is leading the push among Harris advisers for breakthrough moments and innovative appearances. Harris and many around her tend to be dismissive of the value of traditional media, and believe they get more of a boost from putting her in situations like hugging voters during a brief Sunday stop at a spice store in Pittsburgh than she ever would from any interview. Plouffeâ€™s role is in part affected by the simmering tension between different factions â€”carryover Biden aides, new staff who came with Harris, a clutch of Obama alumni who parachuted in together and the core group of advisers who tend to spend the most time with the candidate on the road and at the Naval Observatory â€” although the infighting looks nothing like the dysfunction of Harrisâ€™ 2019 bid. Oâ€™Malley Dillonâ€™s leadership retreat last week, for example, was part therapy for aides coming off their rollercoaster summer. But it was also part information sharing â€” amid the massive divergence in political conditions, ballot propositions and candidates that Harris aides believe could upend the trend of recent elections where states move in regional blocs. This year, what Plouffe is running up against is Democratic trauma from the last two presidential elections that theyâ€™ll miss basics or take advantages for granted. Plouffe himself famously predicted in June 2016 that Hillary Clinton would win over 350 electoral votes, and that was before she was widely seen to have won all three of her debates. And four years ago, Bidenâ€™s polling lead this far out from November was clearer than any that Harris has. Translating the summer enthusiasm into fall work without the enthusiasm draining wonâ€™t be easy, said Dan Kildee, a retiring Democratic congressman from the critical battleground of Michigan. He said heâ€™s heartened that 35,000 new volunteers signed up in his state since Harris became the nominee, but he said that wonâ€™t matter unless theyâ€™re managed and deployed correctly. â€œThe heft of the campaign is greater, but the work is phone calls, itâ€™s door knocks. Itâ€™s the kind of boring stuff done with enough volume and enough repetition that we increase it,â€ Kildee said. â€œThen thereâ€™s the special sauce: can we get some of that magic?â€ Obama is expected to be central in that effort, with aides working to add to his usual slate of late fall battleground campaign rallies â€“ in person or with online influencers, whom heâ€™s been pushing to use their platforms to get followers to vote. The first taste of that will come next Tuesday, for National Voter Registration Day: Obama already recorded videos and other content in Chicago and at home in Washington that his office estimates will be hitting 30 million users across social media, aimed at younger voters. â€œOur boss always wants to push the envelope, and the teams are aligned there. Weâ€™ll definitely be having some fun,â€ an Obama aide told CNN. The former president will kick off his work at a fundraiser heâ€™s hosting for Harris next week in Los Angeles. Former first lady Michelle Obama, who delivered a rallying cry speech in Chicago, is not expected to campaign, instead sticking with her officially non-partisan voter registration efforts. When it comes to volunteers and on-the-ground organizers, Democrats believe they will have an edge over Trump. They think thatâ€™s particularly true after his handpicked new chairs shut down many of the in-state offices the Republican National Committee had opened, outsourcing much of his outreach and turnout operations to outside groups. But much like when many were working on Bidenâ€™s campaign â€” although to a lesser degree â€” Harris aides and other Democratic operatives say they know theyâ€™re still running up against voters who arenâ€™t and wonâ€™t ever really tune in or pay attention to any of the traditional ways of getting in touch. â€œThe big thing we know about those voters is that they werenâ€™t responding before and theyâ€™re voters that donâ€™t respond to traditional media,â€ said Ben Wikler, the Democratic chairman in Wisconsin, where a range of in-person and texting voter-to-voter community outreach has been underway since the spring. â€œBut also we need everyone who does pay attention to traditional mediaâ€”so we have to do both.â€ Mitch Landrieu, the former New Orleans mayor who moved from being a Biden campaign co-chair to a Harris campaign co-chair, told CNN on Thursday that heâ€™s realistic about the difference between the first 50 days of Harrisâ€™ campaign, when she was energizing Democrats whom Biden had sent panicking, and the 53 days left, when she has to try to close the deal. â€œSheâ€™s still trending in the right direction. And every day sheâ€™s won. And every day weâ€™ve actually gone up a little bit,â€ Landrieu said. â€œAt some point in time, you have to stop expecting it to keep going up because thereâ€™s not that many fish left in the sea.â€

Title: In purple North Carolina, Democrats hope to defeat a MAGA candidate for governor even as the presidential race remains close | CNN Politics
Content: Four years ago, North Carolina voters handed Democrats one of the partyâ€™s toughest losses and one of its most consequential wins. Despite years of Democrats hoping that changing demographics in the fast-growing state would tip the presidential race, Donald Trump defeated Joe Biden here by 1 point, his narrowest winning margin in the country. But further down the ballot, voters reelected Democratic Gov. Roy Cooper, who has spent much of the next four years serving as a check on the Republican-controlled legislature and advancing priorities such as Medicaid expansion. With 54 days until the November election, voters in the Tar Heel State seem equally split this year. At the presidential level, Trump and Kamala Harris have increased their campaigning in the state, where both have made multiple visits and ramped up ad spending. On Thursday, Harris will return, rallying supporters in Charlotte and Greensboro. The race to succeed the term-limited Cooper, however, seems to be leaning toward the Democratic nominee, North Carolina Attorney General Josh Stein. Stein and his Democratic allies have covered the airways with millions of dollars worth of devastating TV ads highlighting Republican opponent Mark Robinsonâ€™s past remarks on abortion and a troubled day care center he and his wife ran in the early 2000s â€“ spending the GOP hasnâ€™t yet matched. Prominent state Republicans, including Sen. Thom Tillis and former Gov. Pat McCrory, have declined to endorse Robinson, the incumbent lieutenant governor. Democrats have a new presidential nominee who has energized the base, and recent polls have shown Stein edging toward a double-digit lead. But North Carolina is still a purple state with a history of elections decided by razor-thin margins. Democrats are hoping that Steinâ€™s record as attorney general and his centrist, economy-focused campaign will win over voters, regardless of what happens at the presidential level. Republicans argue that Robinsonâ€™s focus on parental rights in schools will boost him and that conservatives will choose even a controversial Republican over a Democrat come November. Both parties acknowledge that early polling leads donâ€™t preclude close races as past cycles have shown. â€œWe obviously feel good about what weâ€™re seeing in the polling, but this is North Carolina,â€ said a source familiar with the Stein campaignâ€™s thinking. â€œThis is going to be a tight race.â€ Jonathan Felts, the executive director of the North Carolina Republican Council of State committee, said Democrats had failed to finish off Robinson before Labor Day and predicted that Republicansâ€™ core support would stabilize in October. â€œWe are a cantankerous lot who find fault with everything,â€ Felts said of his party. â€œAnd then, when itâ€™s time to actually make a binary decision â€“ Democrat vs. Republican â€“ our base comes home.â€ Historically, North Carolina voters have favored ticket-splitting. In the 12 presidential elections of the past half century, the state has backed the Democratic nominee just twice â€“ Jimmy Carter in 1976 and Barack Obama in 2008. But the state has only elected three Republican governors in the past 100 years â€“ the most recent being McCrory in 2012. McCroryâ€™s 10,000-vote loss in 2016 has been attributed in part to legislation he signed that forced transgender people to use the bathroom of the gender matching their birth certificate in state government buildings. The law, HB2, led to massive boycotts from companies and missed revenue opportunities, before being repealed in 2017. That same year, however, Trump beat former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton by 4 points. â€œThereâ€™s no connection between the gubernatorial ticket and presidential ticket,â€ said North Carolina Republican strategist Paul Shumaker. â€œThereâ€™s still a good 25% of voters who donâ€™t even know who the gubernatorial candidates are right now. The presidential candidates are much more better defined.â€ A Quinnipiac poll of likely voters released this week had Stein leading Robinson 51% to 41% overall, with the attorney general holding a 38- point advantage among women. A Fox News poll from last month found the attorney general up 54% to 43% among registered voters, with a 21-point advantage among women. Both polls showed Stein winning the support of virtually all the Democrats surveyed, leading with independents and capturing the support of about a tenth of Republican voters. Both polls also showed the presidential race with no clear leader. Democrats have swamped Republicans on the airwaves, according to AdImpact data through September 11.  America Works USA, a political action committee allied with the Democratic Governors Association, has spent $18.3 million on TV ads, while Stein has spent more than $29 million in ads touting his work to clear a backlog of rape kits in the state and criticizing Robinson over the day care center he operated with his wife. The most damaging ads have featured Robinsonâ€™s past remarks criticizing abortion. Robinson has said he supports the stateâ€™s 12-week abortion limit, which includes exceptions for rape, incest and the life of the mother, despite his past support for bans with no exceptions. Heâ€™s attributed his opposition to the procedure to his and his wifeâ€™s decision to seek an abortion 30 years ago. â€œEverything Josh Stein and his campaign say about Mark Robinson is either an outright lie or twisted so far out of context it might as well be,â€ Robinson campaign spokesman Mike Lonergan said in a statement. Robinsonâ€™s campaign has spent more than $8.9 million on the airwaves through September 11, and the Republican Governors Association has spent $9.9 million attacking Steinâ€™s law enforcement record. One Robinson ad, in particular, criticized Steinâ€™s handling of racial justice protests in 2020. â€œAs Attorney General, Josh Stein has been intent on keeping North Carolina communities safe â€“ whether it be urging Congress to spend $300 million to detect fentanyl at the border, clearing the rape kit backlog, or putting drug traffickers, murderers, rapists and child sex abusers behind bars,â€ Stein campaign spokeswoman Morgan Hopkins said in a statement. Robinson also has the support of Trump, who called him â€œMartin Luther King on steroidsâ€ as he endorsed the lieutenant governor in March ahead of the stateâ€™s Republican primary. Robinson has embraced the former presidentâ€™s backing and campaigned with him in Asheville last month. There, the lieutenant governor made an argument that many of his own supporters have made for him: Itâ€™s not about the personality or how â€œbrashâ€ Trump may seem, but his policies. â€œWeâ€™re suffering because of bad policy,â€ Robinson said. â€œWe need to get the good times back. And how do we get the good times back? We reelect President Donald Trump to fix this economy.â€ The governorâ€™s race may come down to how much Robinson has turned off moderate and independent voters after years of comments in interviews and Facebook posts that have been criticized as anti-LGBTQ, antisemitic and misogynistic. Stein has sought to capitalize on that history by arguing that Robinson is unfit for the office and framing his inflammatory comments as distractions. â€œWe have to focus on the fundamentals: great schools, solid infrastructure, affordable and accessible health care, safe communities,â€ the attorney general told voters at a campaign event with business leaders this summer. â€œAnd we must leave to the side these job-killing culture wars.â€ Robinson has also made an economic pitch, focused on his experiences growing up in poverty, being laid off and watching his jobs get sent overseas. Susan Myers, an entrepreneur from Pink Hill, North Carolina, said those experiences showed that Robinson has â€œlived a real life.â€ Myers said she was a longtime supporter of the lieutenant governor and had held a fundraiser for him at her home during his 2020 race. â€œI was amazed at the turnout in a very rural area,â€ she told CNN. â€œHeâ€™s a rock star. He draws people across racial and sexual and income and education barriers, and thatâ€™s what we need.â€ She was willing to look past his history of contentious remarks. â€œThere are a lot of lies, a lot of taking a little bit here, a little bit there,â€ Myers said of the criticisms of Robinson. â€œMarkâ€™s not a lifelong politician, so he said things off the cuff that maybe he shouldnâ€™t have said.â€ Democrats say Steinâ€™s record â€“ and his lack of viral moments â€“ is part of his appeal. â€œHe is a public servant,â€ state party chair Anderson Clayton said. â€œHeâ€™s not a showboat. Stein grew up in Chapel Hill, where his father â€“ civil rights attorney Adam Stein â€“ helped found the stateâ€™s first racially integrated law firm. The attorney general received a bachelors degree from Dartmouth and law and public policy degrees from Harvard University. Heâ€™s also highlighted his work clearing the stateâ€™s massive backlog of untested rape kits. During his first term in office, Stein worked with the Republican-controlled legislature to conduct an audit that revealed there were more than 16,000 untested rape kits in the state and to pass legislation to clear the backlog and reform the testing system. Steinâ€™s office announced in April that the backlog had been cleared. Republicans have argued that despite his inflammatory comments, Robinson appeals to working-class North Carolina residents in a way that the Ivy League-educated, two-term attorney general may not. Robinson grew up in Greensboro, the ninth of 10 children, and speaks often of how his mother kept the family afloat after his father died. After serving in the Army Reserves and briefly attending college, Robinson spent years working in furniture manufacturing. In 2022, he received a bachelorâ€™s degree from the University of North Carolina, Greensboro. In 2018, he rose to prominence after his remarks at a Greensboro City Council meeting defending gun ownersâ€™ rights after the Parkland , Florida, school shooting. (Months earlier, Robinson took to Facebook to label survivors of the shooting calling for gun control â€œspoiled, angry, know it all CHILDRENâ€ and â€œmedia prosti-tots.â€) Two years later, he won his first political campaign, for lieutenant governor, in the same cycle that Democratic Gov. Roy Cooper and Stein won second terms. Both candidates have centered their pitch on the economy and education. Earlier this summer, the two shared a stage for the first time at a town hall style event hosted by the Wilmington Business Journal. Stein spoke first, touting his record as attorney general and repeating his warning of â€œjob-killing culture warsâ€ and the memory of the stateâ€™s bathroom law. Then he blasted what he called Robinsonâ€™s â€œdivision and hate,â€ and ran through a list of his opponentâ€™s past comments, including describing homosexuality as â€œfilth,â€ calling public school teachers â€œwicked people,â€ suggesting that Pearl Harbor and 9/11 might have been inside jobs, and referencing women who â€œcanâ€™t keep their skirts downâ€ to explain his support for banning abortion. â€œFriends, being governor is not performative outrage,â€ Stein told the crowd. â€œIt is a real job. Itâ€™s an important job. It is a hard job.â€ When he took the stage minutes later, Robinson said he would be focused on the economy and education. â€œThere are a lot of folks are going to say that Mark Robinson is some culture warrior, is going to be focused on the culture wars. That is not true,â€ he told the crowd. â€œThat is not the message that we have been presenting, and that is not what we will be doing as governor.â€ A few minutes later, however, the topic turned to those battles when Robinson was asked to elaborate on his pledge to remove what he believes to be inappropriate materials from classrooms. He pointed to the book â€œGender Queer,â€ a memoir about coming out as nonbinary and frequent target of bans. Deloris Rhodes, a former high school principal who moved to Wilmington after she retired, said sheâ€™s been following Robinson since he was elected lieutenant governor in 2020. She bristled at his efforts to overhaul public school education in the state. In his 2022 memoir, Robinson called for eliminating science and social studies classes for elementary school students, a proposal he later backed away from, and shuttering the State Board of Education. â€œAnyone that has common sense knows that theyâ€™re going to vote for Josh Stein,â€ Rhodes said. Heather Horak, a 48-year-old Wilmington resident who attended the event, said she appreciates Robinsonâ€™s approach to education policy. Horak is an unaffiliated voter whose politics defy easy categorization. She supported Democratic presidents â€“ including Obama twice â€“ until 2016, when she backed Trump. Her support for Trump this year was only solidified after independent Robert F. Kennedy Jr dropped out and endorsed the former president. At the same time, Horak also supports abortion rights. Horak said she wasnâ€™t focused on negative ads about Robinsonâ€™s conduct because it didnâ€™t affect the issues that matter to her. She wanted people to vote on policy, not emotions, she said. â€œIf â€“ whoever your candidate is â€“ is just triggering your emotions and you say, â€˜I donâ€™t like that person because I think theyâ€™re a bully, I donâ€™t like that person because heâ€™s got a harsh tone,â€™ letâ€™s be realistic and look at the facts,â€ she said. â€œThatâ€™s my biggest concern.â€ CLARIFICATION: This story has been updated to reflect that the ad that criticized Josh Steinâ€™s handling of racial justice protests in 2020 was from Mark Robinsonâ€™s campaign.

Title: Harris campaign guarding against overconfidence after her debate performance sent Democratsâ€™ spirits soaring | CNN Politics
Content: Kamala Harris just roasted her opponent on national television. After months of anticipation, the worldâ€™s biggest pop star finally endorsed her. She is swimming in a veritable ocean of cash. So why is Michigan Democratic Rep. Debbie Dingell still feeling anxious about Novemberâ€™s election? â€œI was ecstatic like every other Democrat as I watched the debate. I thought she got under his skin,â€ Dingell said Thursday on â€œCNN This Morning,â€ before recounting the reality check sheâ€™d been delivered in an early morning phone call from an official in her state. â€œSix-fifty yesterday morning, one of my township supervisors called me and wanted to know what I thought,â€ Dingell said. â€œThat discussion brought me right back down to Earth.â€ Burned before by overconfidence, Democrats this cycle are running against two opponents. Yes, Donald Trump is the name opposite of Harrisâ€™s on the ballot. But it is complacency in their own ranks that many of Harrisâ€™s allies are working just as hard to protect against in the final sprint toward Election Day. Polls provide one reason why. Surveys in battleground states indicate an extraordinarily close contest, perhaps the closest in recent memory, which many Harris allies fear is being obscured by the swell of momentum on Harrisâ€™ side. Trumpâ€™s stranglehold on his own supporters is another. Harrisâ€™s aides view his base of support as highly motivated, and note his favorability is higher than when he lost the 2020 election. Yet perhaps the biggest motivator â€” embossed on the minds of so many operatives who now are working to elect Harris â€” is the memory of 2016, when Hillary Clintonâ€™s campaign believed it was coasting to victory only to see support in the so-called â€œblue wallâ€ crumble. Democrats are hardly in despair. Last monthâ€™s convention in Chicago was practically euphoric in its celebration of a new nominee that, unlike President Joe Biden, does not seem predestined to lose. And Harris herself has embraced the new sense of joy among the party, casting it as the alternative to Trumpâ€™s divisiveness. Yet in practically every conversation, public or private, Harris aides and the candidate herself have interjected with a reality check. They have tempered expectations, tamped down on confidence and announced themselves as the underdog, despite their ostensible success in orchestrating an unprecedented candidate swap 100 days before the election and consolidating new Democratic enthusiasm. Huddled at their campaign headquarters in Wilmington, Delaware, the day after the debate, Harrisâ€™s campaign aides determined the event would likely do little to change the overall trajectory of the race. Their earlier projections that the results in November will amount to a razor-thin margin â€” likely to be as close or closer than the results in 2020 â€” remain the same. Instead, they have developed a plan for the coming days and weeks that will place Harris directly in front of battleground state voters, beginning Thursday in North Carolina and continuing Friday in Pennsylvania. Those stops for the â€œNew Way Forwardâ€ tour arenâ€™t just to any battleground state. Theyâ€™re the states where voting is already about to get underway. And a campaign official tells CNN thatâ€™s no coincidence. North Carolina, a purple state where Harris and running mate Tim Walz will make two stops Thursday, is racing to reprint and send out mail-in ballots after the stateâ€™s Supreme Court ruled Monday to exclude Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has exited the race. About 161,000 people have already requested mail-in ballots, according to the NC Board of Elections. Trump won the state in 2020 by less than half that number of votes. Next week, Harris will participate in a roundtable with rank-and-file members of the influential Teamsters union, which has been withholding an endorsement for the first time in decades. She will also participate in a Q&A session with members of the National Association of Black Journalists, with whom Trump appeared in late July and remarked that Harris â€œturned Black.â€ The campaign is expecting to rake in millions in new funds, with a Harris-helmed fundraiser in Washington on Saturday, an Oprah-headlined virtual event next week and several other high-dollar events in the works, according to people familiar with them. That cash, the campaign has said, must be quickly tabulated and quickly deployed in states where voters are beginning to head to the ballot box. In addition to rallies, Harris also plans more local media interviews in the swing states and appearances that bring her into direct contact with voters. Campaign officials spent part of Wednesday looking through debate footage to identify moments that would make effective television ads. The first spot features Harris framing the race as a choice between â€œtwo very different visions for the country, one that is focused on the future, one that is focused on the past.â€ Even as they applauded Harrisâ€™s success on the debate stage, however, aides and allies remained cautious about declaring victory too early. â€œWe havenâ€™t won anything yet!â€ Doug Emhoff, Harrisâ€™ husband, declared to supporters at a debate watch party in Philadelphia moments after she stepped off stage. â€œWe have a lot of work to do,â€ Harris followed up. The next morning, it was more caution. â€œDebates donâ€™t win elections,â€ Harrisâ€™s team emailed supporters. That type of message is hardly new for a campaign that is looking to maintain its fundraising, motivate its volunteers and convince its pledged voters that they still, in fact, need to cast a ballot. Al Gore even wore an â€œunderdogâ€ costume for Halloween in 1999 as he was seeking the Democratic nomination. Yet the messaging this time appears to go deeper than simply a galvanizing tactic. In battleground states like Dingellâ€™s, where a small slice of undecided voters is likely to determine the next president, Harris and Trump remain in a neck-and-neck contest. While some surveys in Michigan indicate Harris with a small edge, Dingell suggested the numbers could be an illusion. â€œI think Michigan is a dead heat,â€ she said. â€œThereâ€™s just a lot of people in the middle â€¦ itâ€™s just closer than people realize.â€ Not every Democrat on Harrisâ€™s side seems gripped with caution. â€œThis is the easiest election in my lifetime. I love where we are,â€ California Gov. Gavin Newsom said on â€œCBS Morningsâ€ on Tuesday ahead of the debate, rejecting the â€œunderdogâ€ label for Harris: â€œSheâ€™s not. I donâ€™t like hearing about that.â€

Title: Harris campaign seizes on abortion exchange in Tuesdayâ€™s debate in new ad | CNN Politics
Content: The Harris campaign is launching a new abortion-focused ad Thursday, capitalizing on what officials believe was one of the most pivotal exchanges between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump during Tuesdayâ€™s presidential debate. Harrisâ€™ team prepared the vice president to confront Trump on nationwide abortion restrictions. Her aides argue the preparation paid off, crediting her needling him on reproductive rights for throwing him off balance the rest of the debate. And now, theyâ€™re turning that moment into an ad that will run in battleground states, including in Arizona and Nevada where Trump heads this week. The newly released ad includes both candidatesâ€™ responses on abortion on the debate stage. â€œI did a great service in doing it. It took courage to do it, and the Supreme Court had great courage in doing it,â€ Trump said, referring to the overturning of Roe v. Wade. Harris, in response, ran through personal stories of women struggling to get health care while navigating abortion restrictions. â€œI think the American people believe that certain freedoms, in particular, the freedom to make decisions about oneâ€™s own body should not be made by the government,â€ she said. Campaign officials cited the vice presidentâ€™s response as one of the strongest moments of the debate, based on internal data suggesting that the stories of miscarriages and victims of rape and incest resonated the most with undecided voters. In a statement announcing the ad, Harris-Walz campaign manager Julie Chavez Rodriguez said abortion is â€œone of the top issues in this election, and the difference between the candidates could not be clearer.â€ It comes as Harris arrives in North Carolina â€“ a crucial state that President Joe Biden narrowly lost in 2020 but one where campaign officials say theyâ€™re trying to make inroads with voters who may be put off by Trump and controversial GOP gubernatorial candidate Mark Robinson. North Carolina Democratic Gov. Roy Cooper told CNNâ€™s Jeff Zeleny Tuesday he believes Harris will move the needle in his battleground state after her strong showing in Philadelphia. The vice presidentâ€™s focus on protecting abortion rights and health care, Cooper said, could be key to bolstering Democratic efforts to deliver the state in a presidential race for the first time since 2008. Harris campaign officials spent Wednesday poring over footage of the debate to identify key moments to put into new campaign TV and digital ads, according to the campaign, seeking to amplify what they perceive to be the strongest debate exchange. The latest ads are part of $370 million set aside for digital and television between Labor Day and Election Day.

Title: Trump allies do damage control as Harris rides fresh momentum post-debate | CNN Politics
Content: Ex-President Donald Trump is equivocating over the possibility of a second debate with Kamala Harris after his dud display in their first showdown prompted his team and conservative media allies to mount a frantic cleanup operation. Itâ€™s far too early to say whether the tangle in Philadelphia substantially changed the race as Harris beseeches remaining movable voters in swing states to ditch the chaos of the Trump era. But in the aftermath of Tuesdayâ€™s debate, both campaigns are surveying the impact of a critical clash before more than 60 million viewers eight weeks from Election Day. Trump, who took multiple victory laps following President Joe Bidenâ€™s disastrous debate performance in late June, found himself facing the kind of inquest endured by his erstwhile rival. While the ex-presidentâ€™s campaign will not suffer the same fate as Bidenâ€™s shuttered reelection effort, the debate was the latest sign that Trump is still failing to focus on the new challenges posed by Harris and make his own best case. The vice president was basking in a fresh jolt of euphoria among Democrats who perceive an oft-doubted political figure growing in stature with every test she passes. Harrisâ€™ campaign is also leveraging the endorsement of Taylor Swift, which could open a new seam of interest among the pop megastarâ€™s loyal fanbase. But history suggests that a first debate between two candidates is not historically a reliable predictor of who wins the election. Despite Harrisâ€™ strong performance, itâ€™s not yet clear how much progress she made in building the path to 270 electoral votes. Michigan Democratic Rep. Debbie Dingell, who consistently warns Democrats not to take her swing state for granted, told CNNâ€™s Kasie Hunt on Thursday that Trumpâ€™s base is energized and that the race could not be closer. â€œI was ecstatic, like every other Democrat, as I watched the debate. I thought she got under his skin. He reminded much of America about who he was and what he was. She showed people she could be the commander in chief,â€ Dingell said. But, she added: â€œAt 6:50 yesterday morning, one of my township supervisors called me and wanted to know what I thought. And I said, â€˜Well, what did you think?â€™ And that discussion brought me right back down to Earth.â€ â€œI think Michigan is a dead heat,â€ she said. Meanwhile, Harrisâ€™ allies are reinforcing the tone of mockery and attempts to goad Trump that emerged at the Democratic National Convention and that the vice president carried into the debate. Philippe Reines, a former Hillary Clinton aide who played Trump in Harrisâ€™ debate prep, told CNNâ€™s Kaitlan Collins Wednesday that the ex-president has slowed mentally since 2016 and compared him to a â€œmalfunctioning appliance.â€ â€œHe was all over the place but to some extent structured,â€ Reines said, referring to Trump when he took on former Secretary of State Clinton. â€œNow, heâ€™s all over the board.â€ He added: â€œI think heâ€™s losing (his) train of thought and heâ€™s just blurting out the next thing in his mind.â€ Hours after the debate, the political bile briefly eased as Harris and Trump, along with Biden and Republican vice presidential nominee JD Vance, gathered at Ground Zero in New York to honor the 23rd anniversary of the September 11 attacks in 2001. The general election rivals only met for the first time at the debate, but they shared their second handshake in 12 hours in a gesture of national unity orchestrated by former New York City Mayor Mike Bloomberg. In a more light-hearted scene Wednesday, a grinning Biden took the extraordinary step of donning a Trump 2024 baseball cap. Andrew Bates, a White House spokesman, said the president gave a hat to a Trump supporter during a visit to a fire station in Shanksville, Pennsylvania, near where the fourth hijacked jet crashed short of its target on 9/11 after a passenger revolt. The Trump supporter had said that â€œin the same spirit POTUS should put on his Trump cap. He briefly wore it,â€ Bates said. But it was only a temporary respite to the bitter fallout from the debate. The former president did what he always does when presented with unfavorable political facts â€” deny them. He declared on Fox News on Wednesday that he had â€œone of my better debates,â€ despite sweeping negative reviews of his showing. Trump also launched an attack on ABC News, claiming the debate was â€œriggedâ€ and faulting moderators who fact checked him for setting up a â€œthree-to-oneâ€ tag team against him. But one of his newest associates, former independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr., may have inadvertently highlighted Trumpâ€™s deficiencies in the debate even as he tried to praise the ex-president whom he recently endorsed. Kennedy said on Fox News that while Trump won the debate on â€œsubstance,â€ Harris â€œclearly won the debate in terms of her delivery, her polish, her organization and her preparation.â€ â€œI think on substance, President Trump wins in terms of his governance,â€ Kennedy said. â€œBut he didnâ€™t tell that story.â€ Still, Trumpâ€™s complaints were more eagerly picked up among his longtime boosters in conservative media, underscoring the way that the Republican Party always falls in line behind its leader. However, Trumpâ€™s narrative that he was thwarted by two TV anchors sat uneasily with his claim on stage that heâ€™s such an intimidating figure that US enemies were simply scared of him. Trump was correct in arguing that he was fact-checked more thoroughly than Harris on Tuesday night by moderators who missed several chances to correct the vice president or to hold her to account for dodging questions. But Harris said nothing that compared to the gusher of untruths from the former president, which included a claim that Haitian immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, were slaying and eating residentsâ€™ dogs and cats. (That racist claim was debunked Wednesday by Ohioâ€™s Republican Gov. Mike DeWine, who said there was â€œno credible evidence.â€) Adopting a more sinister tone in his interview with Fox, the former president accused ABC of putting on a â€œrigged dealâ€ and warned officials â€œought to take away their license.â€ His comments were ominous considering heâ€™s vowed to wage a presidency of â€œretributionâ€ if he is elected to a second term in November that would include the use of presidential power to punish his enemies. The former president also Wednesday publicly toyed with the idea of a second debate, after the Harris campaign challenged him to another round. But the former president, smarting from his treatment at the hands of the vice president on Tuesday, doesnâ€™t seem to be in a hurry to renew the performance. One the one hand, he may have little incentive to show up again given that he was widely seen to have suffered a drubbing on Tuesday. But if the polls show him trailing in the run-up to the election, there might be a rationale for a do-over. The Harris campaign has a similar conundrum. Thereâ€™s a case for the vice president folding her tent given that she might not be able to repeat Tuesdayâ€™s performance. Trump, however, is trying to change perceptions of the debate after the fact. â€œIn the World of Boxing or UFC, when a Fighter gets beaten or knocked out, they get up and scream, â€˜I DEMAND A REMATCH, I DEMAND A REMATCH!â€™ Well, itâ€™s no different with a Debate. She was beaten badly last nigh. Every Poll has us WINNING,â€ he wrote on Truth Social, â€œso why would I do a Rematch?â€ As is often the case, the ex-presidentâ€™s reading of polls was exaggerated. A flash CNN poll performed by SSRS after the debate found that watchers thought Harris put in a stronger performance by 63% to 37%. History suggests that it takes at least a week for the full impact of a debate to filter down into the electorate. And the fundamentals of the neck-and-neck race with Harris still seem to favor the former president, whose campaign ads are targeting the vice president over the current administrationâ€™s record on the economy, including high prices, inflation and immigration, with an intensity and level of focus that Trump as a candidate has come nowhere near matching. Trumpâ€™s running mate has also been more effective at delivering a sharp political message than his boss. He weaved a dismissal of the Swift endorsement for Harris into a wider attack on the vice president on Fox News. â€œWhen grocery prices go by up by 20%, it hurts most Americans. It doesnâ€™t hurt Taylor Swift,â€ Vance said. â€œWhen housing prices become unaffordable, it doesnâ€™t affect Taylor Swift or any other billionaire. It does affect middle-class Americans all over our country.â€ The challenging political backdrop explains why things are still tense at Harris headquarters in Wilmington, Delaware. A senior campaign aide told CNNâ€™s MJ Lee that the assumption was that the election remained a 50-50 proposition. â€œItâ€™ll be incredibly close. We cannot take our foot off the gas, even when the moment feels really good,â€ the aide said. Harris also faces choices beyond whether sheâ€™ll agree to another debate. While her performance was stylistically strong on Tuesday, she still dodged key questions â€” for instance, the very first one on whether she believes Americans are better off now or when Trump was in office. The Trump campaign is sure to keep up its drumbeat of complaints that sheâ€™s avoiding deeper media scrutiny. And there are many signs that voters want more substance from the Democratic nominee. Several voters who are undecided or leaning toward Harris or Trump, but open to changing their candidate, told CNNâ€™s John King that Harris did well in the debate but several also cautioned she was not sufficiently specific in explaining her policies. â€œKamala Harris says she wants to lift up the middle class, but how?â€ said Linda Rooney, who lives in the Philadelphia suburbs and voted for former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley in the primary. She also voiced concern about Harris shifting her positions on fracking and other issues. Such doubts are evident in recent national polls too. But they also reflect the fresh complications Trump has caused for himself with his underwhelming debate performance: He may have squandered his best and last chance to expose Harris over those vulnerabilities in front of tens of millions of voters.

Title: WNBA star Caitlin Clark explains why she liked Taylor Swiftâ€™s post endorsing Kamala Harris | CNN
Content: WNBA star Caitlin Clark hinted at her political beliefs ahead of this yearâ€™s US election by liking a social media post from Taylor Swift endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris, but she stopped short of endorsing a candidate when asked by reporters on Wednesday. On Tuesday, Swift ended speculation about whether she would endorse a particular candidate ahead of Novemberâ€™s election by telling her Instagram followers that she would be voting for Kamala Harris and Tim Walz. Clark was one of more than 10 million people to like the post but stopped short of formally endorsing Harris herself. â€œI have this amazing platform, so I think the biggest thing would be to just encourage people to register to vote,â€ Clark told reporters on Wednesday, when asked about her decision to like the post. â€œThatâ€™s the biggest thing I can do with the platform that I have and thatâ€™s the same thing Taylor (Swift) did. â€œContinue to educate yourself on the candidates that we have, the policies that theyâ€™re supporting â€“ I think thatâ€™s the biggest thing you can do. And thatâ€™s what I would recommend to every single person that has the opportunity in our country.â€ Since bursting into the WNBA following her remarkable college career, Clark has had to navigate the challenges that come with being such an influential figure. Earlier this year, the 22-year-old said it was â€œdisappointingâ€ to see people using her name to push their own agendas, especially when it comes to racism and misogyny. This, though, appears to be the first indication of Clarkâ€™s political leanings ahead of the presidential election. The WNBA and its players have regularly engaged with societal and political issues. At this yearâ€™s Olympic Games in Paris, Team USAâ€™s womenâ€™s basketball team emphasized their endorsement of Harrisâ€™ presidential bid before going on to win gold in a dramatic final against France. Womenâ€™s basketball players have also had influential voices in key elections before. In 2020, the Atlanta Dream protested against the teamâ€™s then co-owner â€“ then Sen. Kelly Loeffler, who was running for reelection against Rev. Raphael Warnock â€“ over her opposition to the Black Lives Matter movement. That race ended up going to a run-off and Warnock defeated Loeffler. Heâ€™s now serving as a senator from Georgia.

Title: September 12, 2024, presidential campaign news | CNN Politics
Content: Our live coverage has ended. Follow the latest 2024 election news here or read through the posts below. Pete Buttigieg on Thursday slammed former President Donald Trumpâ€™s recent false claims that migrants are eating pets, saying itâ€™s a strategy to distract from the Republican presidential nomineeâ€™s record. In recent days, Trump and his allies, including running mate JD Vance, have promoted false claims that Haitian migrants in Ohio are killing and eating family pets. Trump repeated the conspiracy theory during the ABC presidential debate Tuesday night, although the City of Springfield and the local police have said theyâ€™ve seen no evidence for the claim. Buttigieg, who spoke in his personal capacity but serves as transportation secretary in the Biden administration, said that while he thinks it is a distraction technique, â€œit contributes to this bigger picture of demonizing immigrants.â€ Buttigieg praised Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ debate performance but stressed that groundwork and organizing is more important to win the race. John Legend took to Instagram to respond to Donald Trumpâ€™s baseless claims about Haitian immigrants eating pets in the singerâ€™s hometown of Springfield, Ohio. Hereâ€™s what he said: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz on Thursday praised Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ debate performance, while warning Michigan voters that the fight to win battleground states is not over. The Democratic vice presidential candidate said Harris â€œcommanded the roomâ€ on Tuesday at the ABC News presidential debate. â€œLetâ€™s be very clear, none of us were surprised at what happened there,â€ and saying â€œno pun intendedâ€ that Harris had the â€œupper handâ€ from the start, referencing the vice president initiating a handshake with her GOP rival. As former President Donald Trump says there will not be another presidential debate, Walz said he thinks â€œhell, every day we should do another one,â€ though, he added, â€œitâ€™s not going to happen.â€ He asked the room if they had â€œeating catsâ€ on their debate bingo cards. The crowd responded by chanting â€œweâ€™re not eating catsâ€ in the same cadence as the campaignâ€™s now-signature â€œweâ€™re not going backâ€ chant.  His comments were in reference to a false rumor about Haitian immigrants in Ohio eating their neighborsâ€™ cats that Trump promoted at the debate. Former President Donald Trump announced Thursday he would not participate in another presidential debate with Vice President Kamala Harris. Trump reiterated this during a campaign rally in Tucson, Arizona, after making the announcement on social media. Harrisâ€™ campaign previously called for another debate. She doubled down on that call during a rally in Charlotte on Thursday, saying â€œI believe we owe it to the voters to have another debate because this election and what is at stake could not be more important.â€ Here are other headlines you should know: After the debate: The Taylor Swift effect: New ads launched: Lawsuits: Trump campaign proposals: More headlines to know: A noticeable contingent of students from Bennett College were among the supporters at Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ Greensboro rally Friday evening.   There are nearly a dozen historically Black Colleges and Universities across North Carolina and the campaign is engaged in direct outreach with them.  Harris, a Howard University alum, recently issued a call to action to these students in an open letter.  Bennett is one of only two all-women historically Black colleges in the country. Spelman College in Georgia is the other. Self-described â€œproud Bennett Belleâ€ Jasmine Rawls introduced Harris and described her excitement as a first-time voter.  â€œWhen I go to that voting booth, I will remember that Vice President Harris and Gov. Walz are the only candidates on that ballot that are fighting for a new way forward,â€ said Rawls. Kamiyah McDowell, 19, â€” who is studying elementary education â€” said the debate was â€œnerve wreckingâ€ to watch both as a college student and as Black woman.   McDowell says sheâ€™s most fearful about â€œhow the public is going to react to the winner.â€  Former President Donald Trump on Thursday continued attacking the moderators at ABCâ€™s presidential debate and repeated debunked conspiracy theories about migrants taking peopleâ€™s pets in Springfield, Ohio.  Trump again claimed migrants in Springfield were stealing peopleâ€™s pets, which is a debunked conspiracy theory that he also promoted during the presidential debate.  â€œTheyâ€™re taking the geese. You know where the geese are? In the park. In the lake. And even walking off with their pets. â€˜My dogâ€™s been taken, my dogâ€™s been stolen,â€™ this can only happen, these people are the worst,â€ Trump said.  The GOP standard-bearer also attacked Vice President Kamala Harris over her debate performance and said, â€œShe claimed I want to monitor womenâ€™s pregnancies. I donâ€™t want to, I donâ€™t want to do that. â€œItâ€™s a total lie. I donâ€™t want to do that. Women, I wonâ€™t be following you to the hospital monitoring.â€ For more context, hereâ€™s our fact check on the ABC presidential debate Former President Donald Trump on Thursday announced that, if reelected, he would push for legislation that would end taxes on overtime pay.  Trump said â€œthat gives people more of an incentive to work. It gives the companies a lot, itâ€™s a lot easier to get the people.â€  The former president previously announced he would push to end taxes on tips and proposed that seniors should not pay taxes on Social Security.  GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene criticized far-right activist Laura Loomer on Thursday, saying that her â€œrhetoric and hateful toneâ€ is concerning and a problem and â€œdoesnâ€™t represent MAGA as a whole.â€ The comments from Greene, a Georgia Republican who has her own high-profile history of incendiary and inflammatory remarks, come after the congresswoman called on Loomer to take down an X post, in which Loomer said if Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris, who is half Indian, wins, â€œthe White House will smell like curry & White House speeches will be facilitated via a call center.â€ Asked by CNNâ€™s Manu Raju if she would encourage Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump not to keep close contact with Loomer, Greene said, â€œThis is such an important election. I donâ€™t think she has the experience or the right mentality to advise a very important presidential election.â€ Itâ€™s the latest sign of infighting on the far-right as the presidential election nears, highlighting tension and divisions among Trump supporters over how the Republican Party and its presidential nominee should position itself to voters. Appearing dazed and flustered by an unfamiliar and fast-changing political landscape upended by Harris becoming the Democratic presidential nominee, Trump has unleashed a torrent of mean-spirited missives, race-baiting insults and conspiratorial broadsides that even close allies and donors have acknowledged as unproductive in recent days. Loomer has been on a handful of trips with Trump, appears often at events where he is speaking and there have been times her bombastic social media posts have appeared to preview Trumpâ€™s next line of attack. Read more about Greeneâ€™s criticism here Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ campaign raised $47 million in the 24 hours following the vice presidentâ€™s debate against Donald Trump Tuesday night, according to a campaign official, making it, so far, one of the strongest single fundraising days of the vice presidentâ€™s campaign.  The donations came from around 600,000 donors, the official said, and was â€œoverwhelminglyâ€ fueled by grassroots supporters. The official did not specify how the campaign is defining grassroots supporters. Jen Oâ€™Malley Dillon, campaign chair, said in a statement that the haulâ€œreflects a strong and growing coalition of Americans united behind Vice President Harrisâ€™ candidacy that knows the stakes this November, and are doing their part to defeat Donald Trump this November.â€ However, Oâ€™Malley Dillon added that â€œthis momentum cannot be taken for granted.â€  The statement comes as CNN has previously reported that even after a strong debate performance against Trump, the Harris campaign is insisting that they believe the election will be tough and very close, and that one night would not have changed the trajectory of the race. Vice President Kamala Harris highlighted the contrasts with former President Donald Trump, criticizing him for his answers on several policy issues during his debate performance on Tuesday night while reiterating he was unfit for the presidency. During Tuesday nightâ€™s debate, Trump said he has â€œconcepts of a planâ€ to replace the Affordable Care Act, something he previously promised to do. Harris responded that Trump tried dozens of times to get rid of the Affordable Care Act and touted the Biden administrationâ€™s work to work to lower prescription drug costs and cap the cost of insulin. She also said she would strengthen the ACA if she were elected president.  The vice president also noted what she said was at stake in the election, specifically womenâ€™s reproductive freedom, and reminded a crowd of supporters in Charlotte, North Carolina, that Trump would not commit to vetoing an abortion ban when asked on the debate stage. Harris also slammed the former president as somebody who was â€œnot fit to be president of the United States, and should never again occupy our nationâ€™s highest office.â€ Some context: Since Harris replaced President Joe Biden at the top of the Democratic ticket, North Carolina is again seen as competitive, and she and Trump have both campaigned there. Barack Obama won the state in 2008, the only time a Democratic candidate for the White House had carried the Tar Heel state in nearly five decades. A federal appeals court on Thursday denied former President Donald Trumpâ€™s effort to delay his sentencing in the criminal hush money case because the state judge overseeing the matter already postponed the date. Trump asked the New York-based appeals court to get involved after a federal judge denied his request to move the state case to federal court. While the case was on appeal, New York state Judge Juan Merchan, who oversees the state case, agreed to move Trumpâ€™s sentencing, then set for September 18, until after the November presidential election, in part to avoid the appearance of aiding one political party or another. The former presidentâ€™s lawyers argued that even with the state adjournment, they wanted the appeals court to step in and put the case on hold until they can fully litigate their challenge to Trumpâ€™s conviction on 34 counts of falsifying business records following the US Supreme Courtâ€™s ruling on presidential immunity this summer. Rose Goute Creole restaurant does a bustling business in Springfield, Ohio, with clientele drawn to its heaping displays of patties and doughnuts, and pots of perfumed rice, fried pork and fish, and golden plantains. Rosena Jean Louis runs the front, offering free cups of a powerful black coffee and patiently managing a jostling lunch crowd. She and her coworkers are proud of the food they serve, feeding a Haitian expatriate community that has grown quickly in Springfield over the past few years. â€œIâ€™m always working at the restaurant,â€ she told CNN. â€œEveryone likes the food I cook.â€ But when asked about a lie that has taken hold in some corners of the internet that their countrymen are stealing and eating peopleâ€™s pets, she rolls her eyes in exasperation. Local officials have repeatedly tried to end the rumor. Springfield officials have told press and city commission meetings that are no credible reports of animal abuse â€œby individuals within the immigrant community.â€ The stateâ€™s highest Republican official, Gov. Mike DeWine, also dismissed the rumor firmly on Wednesday, noting there was â€œno evidence of that at all.â€ â€œThe internet can be quite crazy sometimes,â€ DeWine told CBS in an interview. â€œMayor Rue of Springfield says, no, thereâ€™s no truth in that. They have no evidence of that, at all. So, I think we go with what the mayor says. He knows his city.â€ Read more about the debate in Springfield Former President Donald Trump on Thursday said he would not participate in another presidential debate.   Trump debated President Joe Biden in June and Vice President Kamala Harris earlier this week. Harrisâ€™ campaign had called for another debate after she and Trump faced off on ABC on Tuesday.  For now, the Harris campaign says it does not take Donald Trumpâ€™s comment at face value.  â€œHe changes his position every day,â€ a senior adviser said. â€œI predict there will be another.â€ This post has been updated with comment from a senior Harris adviser. Asked explicitly if he would consider privatizingthe Veterans Affairs health system, Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance said heâ€™s in favor of giving veterans â€œmore optionality.â€ â€œI think Iâ€™d consider â€” and Donald Trump was really good at this, doesnâ€™t get enough credit for this particular innovation â€” but giving veterans more choice, right?â€ Vance said on â€œThe Shawn Ryan Showâ€ podcast. Vance described a situation where the nearest VA hospital might be over 100 miles away in a rural area.  Vance also spoke about gutting the federal workforce in Washington, DC, including at the VA.  â€œProbably 90, 95% of the people who work at the VA are fantastic human beings. But then youâ€™ve got, like, a small slice of the VA thatâ€™s bad apples that make it really hard for everybody else to do their job,â€ Vance said. A judge on Thursday threw out three charges in the sweeping Georgia election subversion case, including two charges that former President Donald Trump is facing. The decision hasnâ€™t yet been formally applied to Trump because his case has been paused pending appeals. In a separate ruling, Fulton County Judge Scott McAfee also upheld the marquee racketeering charge in the case, which Trump is also facing. These rulings only narrowly went into effect for former Trump lawyer John Eastman and Georgia state Sen. Shawn Still, who were involved in the 2020 fake electors plot. Their cases are not currently paused. Trump was only named in two of the three charges that McAfee threw out Thursday. Read more about the case. President Joe Biden donned a Trump cap while visiting a firehouse in Pennsylvania on Wednesday as a gesture of â€œbipartisan unityâ€ while he commemorated the 23rd anniversary of the September 11 attacks, according to press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre. Pictures and videos showed Biden, who was speaking to a crowd at a firehouse near Shanksville Pennsylvania â€“ where United Flight 93 crashed after passengers tried thwarting a hijacking â€“ momentarily putting a Trump hat on at the urging of others in the crowd. Many in the crowd were wearing Trump-branded gear. Bidenâ€™s message, Jean-Pierre said, was â€œthat we needed to go back to that bipartisan unity as a country. And so he made those remarks, impromptu remarks, to some of the folks who were there on that day, and he offered a presidential hat to a man who was wearing a Trump cap. And in return, the man said that, in the same spirit, the president should put on his Trump cap. And so the President did very briefly, and thatâ€™s what happened.â€ She added: â€œIt was, it was truly a back and forth about unity, and the president remembering a moment in time after a horrific incident on that day and how the country did come together. It didnâ€™t matter what political party you were part of. It didnâ€™t matter. We came together as a country because we lost so many souls, thousands of souls, more than 2,000 that day.â€ The White House on Thursday said recent social media comments from Laura Loomer, a far-right conspiracy theorist who has been spending time with former President Donald Trump, are â€œrepugnant.â€ White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said â€œno leader should ever associateâ€ with someone who spreads â€œracist poison.â€ Jean-Pierre was asked about a tweet Loomer posted on Sunday denigrating Vice President Kamala Harris. Loomer traveled to Tuesdayâ€™s presidential debate on Trumpâ€™s plane and accompanied the former president on Wednesday as he commemorated the 23rd anniversary of the September 11, 2001 attacks. â€œNo leader should ever associate with someone who spreads this kind of ugliness â€” this kind of racist poison. Thatâ€™s what this is â€” and who continues to fan these types of dangerous and insulting conspiracy theories, like the false notion that the tragic 9/11 attacks were an inside job,â€ she added, a reference to a video Loomer posted last year that suggested a government conspiracy was responsible for the attacks. Read more about Loomerâ€™s possible influence on Trump. Vice President Kamala Harris called for another presidential debate on Thursday, minutes after former President Donald Trump said on social media that he would not participate in a third debate. She slammed Trump for delivering the same â€œtired playbookâ€ during the debate on Tuesday, reiterating itâ€™s time for the country to move forward. House Republicans are flirting with the idea of forcing a government shutdown over the issue of noncitizens voting in US elections. Government funding authority runs out on September 30, and House Speaker Mike Johnson â€” at the all-caps urging of former President Donald Trump in social media posts â€“ wants to pair a temporary spending bill to keep the government running along with a bill that would require proof of citizenship for every American in order to register to vote. With that in mind, hereâ€™s a look at the evidence in the specific states Johnson mentions about the infinitesimal number of undocumented people registering to vote or actually voting in US elections. Georgia In 2022, Georgia, which has more than 7 million registered voters, announced the results of the first-ever citizenship review of its voter rolls. It found a grand total of 1,634 people â€œwho had attempted to register to vote were not able to be verified,â€ according to a statement that year from Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, a Republican. They were placed into â€œpending citizenshipâ€ status. Pennsylvania In a state with more than 8.6 million registered voters, an admitted glitch in Pennsylvaniaâ€™s voter registration process enabled noncitizens legally in the US to unwittingly register to vote for a time. Between 2006 and 2017, when the glitch was discovered, at least 168 unauthorized people are thought to have been registered to vote in Philadelphia, a city of more than 1.5 million people. Read about the situation in other states here Kamala Harris just roasted her opponent on national television. After months of anticipation, the worldâ€™s biggest pop star finally endorsed her. She is swimming in a veritable ocean of cash. So why is Michigan Democratic Rep. Debbie Dingell still feeling anxious about Novemberâ€™s election? Burned before by overconfidence, Democrats this cycle are running against two opponents. Yes, Donald Trump is the name opposite of Harrisâ€™ on the ballot. But it is complacency in their own ranks that many of Harrisâ€™ allies are working just as hard to protect against in the final sprint toward Election Day. Polls provide one reason why. Surveys in battleground states indicate an extraordinarily close contest, perhaps the closest in recent memory, which many Harris allies fear is being obscured by the swell of momentum on Harrisâ€™ side. Trumpâ€™s stranglehold on his own supporters is another. Harrisâ€™ aides view his base of support as highly motivated and note his favorability is higher than when he lost the 2020 election. Yet perhaps the biggest motivator â€” embossed on the minds of so many operatives who now are working to elect Harris â€” is the memory of 2016, when Hillary Clintonâ€™s campaign believed it was coasting to victory only to see support in the so-called â€œblue wallâ€ crumble. Democrats are hardly in despair. Last monthâ€™s convention in Chicago was practically euphoric in its celebration of a new nominee that, unlike President Joe Biden, does not seem predestined to lose. And Harris herself has embraced the new sense of joy among the party, casting it as the alternative to Trumpâ€™s divisiveness. Yet in practically every conversation, public or private, Harris aides and the candidate herself have interjected with a reality check. They have tempered expectations, tamped down on confidence and announced themselves as the underdog, despite their ostensible success in orchestrating an unprecedented candidate swap 100 days before the election and consolidating new Democratic enthusiasm. Keep reading here about where things stand in the Harris campaign. Huddled at their campaign headquarters in Wilmington, Delaware, the day after the debate, Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ campaign aides determined the event would likely do little to change the overall trajectory of the race. Their earlier projections that the results in November will amount to a razor-thin margin â€” likely to be as close or closer than the results in 2020 â€” remain the same. Instead, they have developed a plan for the coming days and weeks that will place Harris directly in front of battleground state voters, beginning Thursday in North Carolina and continuing Friday in Pennsylvania. Those stops for the â€œNew Way Forwardâ€ tour arenâ€™t just to any battleground state. Theyâ€™re the states where voting is already about to get underway. And a campaign official tells CNN thatâ€™s no coincidence. North Carolina, a purple state where Harris and running mate Tim Walz will make two stops Thursday, is racing to reprint and send out mail-in ballots after the stateâ€™s Supreme Court ruled Monday to exclude Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has exited the race. About 161,000 people have already requested mail-in ballots, according to the NC Board of Elections. Trump won the state in 2020 by less than half that number of votes. Next week, Harris will participate in a roundtable with rank-and-file members of the influential Teamsters union, which has been withholding an endorsement for the first time in decades. She will also participate in a Q&A session with members of the National Association of Black Journalists, with whom Trump appeared in late July and remarked that Harris â€œturned Black.â€ The campaign is expecting to rake in millions in new funds, with a Harris-helmed fundraiser in Washington on Saturday, an Oprah-headlined virtual event next week and several other high-dollar events in the works, according to people familiar with them. That cash, the campaign has said, must be quickly tabulated and quickly deployed in states where voters are beginning to head to the ballot box. In addition to rallies, Harris also plans more local media interviews in swing states and appearances that bring her into direct contact with voters. Keep reading here about Harrisâ€™ campaign plans. Taylor Swiftâ€™s endorsement of Vice President Kamala Harris brought an immediate, tangible boost for two key websites promoting voter registration, the latest signal of the superstar singerâ€™s political potency.  The link that Swift shared in her Instagram story late Tuesday routed fans to Vote.gov, which is the federal governmentâ€™s voting registration site.  That marked a significant spike to the siteâ€™s average traffic. For instance, from September 3 to 9, the site received about 30,000 visitors per day. Vote.gov received â€œa total of 726,523 visitors between September 10-11, 2024,â€ the spokesperson noted.  The nonprofit, nonpartisan organization Vote.org also saw a significant spike in engagement around the debate and Swiftâ€™s endorsement.  On Wednesday, there were over 27,000 new registrations and over 80,000 people who verified their registration status on Vote.org, a spokesperson said.  Swift encouraged her supporters to register to vote and research early voting information.  â€œIâ€™ve done my research, and Iâ€™ve made my choice. Your research is all yours to do, and the choice is yours to make,â€ Swift wrote in an Instagram post on Tuesday night. With margins expected to be tight in battleground states this November, Swiftâ€™s capacity to shake up the presidential race could make a difference.  Swift also urged fans to register to vote while accepting an award at the 2024 MTV Video Music Awards on Wednesday. Vote.org doesnâ€™t have post-VMA data at this point. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer continued on Thursday to tie former President Donald Trump to the conservative Heritage Foundationâ€™s Project 2025, a conservative policy roadmap for a Republican presidential administration. Trump has said that he is unfamiliar with the project, which Schumer called, â€œan American nightmare. The most conservative, unhinged and extreme agenda weâ€™ve seen in modern times.â€ He added, â€œTrumpâ€™s first term in office wouldnâ€™t hold a candle to the ideas in Project 2025.â€ Schumer and several of his Senate Democratic colleagues pointed to parts of the proposal that are â€œlaying the groundwork for a national abortion ban,â€ and note that it includes a plan to abolish the Department of Education. They also argued that the mortgage policies would â€œmake it harder for Americans to own a home.â€  â€œThis is sinister stuff,â€ said Schumer. â€œThe vast majority of Americans oppose them, yet it is precisely what the hard right is promising the American people if Donald Trump returns to office.â€ Pressed on Republicansâ€™ insistence that Trump would not sign a national abortion ban â€”although Trump did not explicitly rule it out at Tuesday nightâ€™s presidential debate â€“ the majority leader said, â€œlook at everything heâ€™s said over the yearsâ€¦No one believes him. Everybody knows what heâ€™s going to do.â€ More about Project 2025: The 920-page document was organized by The Heritage Foundation think tank and developed in significant part by people who served in Trumpâ€™s administration. Trump has publicly distanced himself from the initiative, calling unspecified Project 2025 ideas â€œseriously extreme.â€   Project 2025â€™s proposals for right-wing policies and a radical reshaping of the executive branch have become frequent targets of Democratic criticism. A Harris campaign official previously said the campaign has â€œmade a deliberate decision to brand all of Trumpâ€™s policiesâ€ as â€œProject 2025,â€ since they believe â€œit has stuck with voters.â€  Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance said he believes former President Donald Trumpâ€™s across-the-board tariff proposals are part of a negotiation tactic and claimed that tariffs are â€œnot alwaysâ€ inflationary.  â€œWhen people say these tariffs are going to have an effect, Donald Trump already imposed specific tariffs on specific industries. You didnâ€™t see the negative consequences come to light. In fact, what you saw was rising wages and rising take home pay. So, when people say you canâ€™t do this in a narrow way, you canâ€™t do it in a broad-based way, I just think that doesnâ€™t actually fit with reality,â€ Vance said.  Trump has said that if elected, he would impose tariffs of up to 20% on every foreign import coming into the US, as well as another tariff upward of 60% on all Chinese imports and 10% across-the-board tariff on imports from other nations. He also said he would impose a â€œ100% tariffâ€ on countries that shift away from using the US dollar. What experts say: Maury Obstfeld, senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, told CNN that such high levies would raise prices on consumers, especially if they were applied widely â€” although he cautioned that itâ€™s unclear under what conditions Trump would impose 100% tariffs. Christine McDaniel, a former senior trade official in the George W. Bush administration, called the idea â€œcrazyâ€ and â€œsilly season campaign rhetoric.â€ Alex Durante, an economist at the Tax Foundation, a right-leaning think tank, told CNN that 100% tariffs would threaten the economy. Attorney General Merrick Garland slammed efforts to turn the Justice Department into a â€œpolitical weaponâ€ during a fiery speech Thursday to department staff and US attorneys from across the country. Garland decried the â€œescalation of attacksâ€ against career staff in years through â€œconspiracy theories, dangerous falsehoods, efforts to bully and intimidate career public servants by repeatedly and publicly singling them out, and threats of actual violence.â€ The attorney generalâ€™s comments come as former President Donald Trump has claimed that the Justice Department has been weaponized against him amid his criminal prosecutions and suggested that he would politicize the department should he return to the Oval Office. Neither Trump nor his allies were mentioned by name. But Trump and his associates have publicly discussed plans to dismantle the department and its law enforcement components like the FBI, or to prosecute his political enemies. â€œOur norms are a promise that we will not allow this nation to become a country where law enforcement is treated as an apparatus of politics,â€ Garland added to applause. Garland also thanked the prosecutors and Justice Department staff for refusing to â€œbend to politicsâ€ and â€œbreak under pressure.â€ Read more about Garlandâ€™s remarks. The Harris campaign is launching a new abortion-focused ad Thursday, capitalizing on what officials believe was one of the most pivotal exchanges between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump during Tuesdayâ€™s presidential debate. Harrisâ€™ team prepared the vice president to confront Trump on nationwide abortion restrictions. Her aides argue the preparation paid off, crediting her needling him on reproductive rights for throwing him off balance the rest of the debate. And now, theyâ€™re turning that moment into an ad that will run in battleground states, including in Arizona and Nevada where Trump heads this week. The newly released ad includes both candidatesâ€™ responses on abortion on the debate stage. â€œI did a great service in doing it. It took courage to do it, and the Supreme Court had great courage in doing it,â€ Trump said, referring to the overturning of Roe v. Wade. Harris, in response, ran through personal stories of women struggling to get health care while navigating abortion restrictions. â€œI think the American people believe that certain freedoms, in particular, the freedom to make decisions about oneâ€™s own body should not be made by the government,â€ she said.
